description:
I found this class to be very conceptually unrigorous and a waste of tuition. I think more could have been done to teach the inner mechanics of networks. This is NOT a fault of the teacher, I think this class was not set up for success. I'm surprised this was even offered by uci.

99% of this class was reading and memorizing concepts.

Every networking class at UCI seems to be bad. His is just the easiest. The exams were not bad but I had to do a lot of textbook reading. His homework are mathy but the tests are purely conceptual. I skipped his lectures as he spoke too slow for me and I opted to use the textbook and yt to learn online. Overall, class is mid.

You can not rely on the lectures alone. He does not give enough info for you to do well without reading pretty much the entire book that he uses for the class. Hundreds of pages compressed into 10 weeks is a lot, however there are a lot of useful youtube videos (made by the author of the book) that are helpful. Curve is also generous
Extremely Difficult; Exams were very confusing and stressful

His lectures and slides are below par. I stopped attending because of how useless it was to me. He talks a lot but it's not engaging at all, so it goes in one ear and out the other. I purely rely on the book to learn the material since the slides barely provide any info. I wish he put more effort into his slides and how he lectures. I'd avoid him.

Really easy class. You will understand on a surface level how computer networks work. 
The lecture are BORING, and the slides will give you the surface knowledge of the topic, the book goes much more in depth. This is not his fault, but UCI as this class should be tought in 2 quarters. 
HW are really easy, midterms too. Just read the slides!

There are no good CS132 professor so far, but I heard this was marginally "better." The guy is nice, but lectures are boring and useless. Homework is taught in discussion, not from the lectures. Slides are bare bones as well, so you'll have to resort to the textbook. UCI is doing a massive disservice by having no good networks professor.

Of the 132 professors, he's probably the easiest. Lectures are pretty boring, but the midterm and final were not too bad if you memorize the slides. If you want to learn, the textbook is good but long. There's a gracious curve (80s --> A). 5 HWs but discussion videos go over how to do the problems. Tests are theory only, MC + short answer.

20% midterm, 40% final, 40% assignments, 1 extra credit assignment worth 5%. Lectures are good, rewatch them, he goes over a lot of the material needed for midterm/final. Textbook is helpful if you need additional understanding. Discussion videos helpful for assignments. I recommend this class, it is relatively low effort and interesting.

60% of your grade is based on the midterm and final, the other 40% is 4 small assignments... Lectures are also not helpful as the professor tends to easily sidetrack into unrelated topics. Reading is your best bet at learning for assignments but it can be extremely confusing. Mainly got through this class with my existing networking experience.

Do not take the Prof unless you have to. I gave up after a few lectures because it is nearly impossible to follow what he was trying to deliver. I self studied the entire course, and join the discord group to help each other out. Otherwise, this class will be very difficult, heavy reading, homework is not too hard.

He deserves >3.3. The lectures are HARD to understand even with recordings due to his thick accent. This class is reading-intensive (700+ pages), but you can get the Notion outline on Discord. Remember to skim over the slides with the outline for the tests or you will miss a lot (e.g. QoS characterizations). Despite curving, this class can be hard.

Probably one of the worst classes I've ever taken. The expectations are unclear and the professors and TAs are unresponsive. There is way too much material to memorize. Overall horrible class and professor.
Computer networks is a very interesting topic. A lot of concepts and some math and probability on homework. Test is heavy 30% MC 70% open questions. Knowledge Professor and great class.

Levorato is the man. He's very knowledgeable with the subject, although sometimes I felt like he was going in circles. His midterms and finals were fair and the homework assignments were easy. Lecture slides are useful, but the textbook reading is your best option to do well on the exams.

This class must have changed since the 2017 reviews, as the tests are all conceptual now, no computation. Depending on your strengths, this could be a good or bad thing. Lecture slides are horrible so you have to do some textbook reading. Most concepts are not challenging if you put in a solid amount of time, it's just A LOT of material
Boring lectures but fair assignments and tests

She is an amazing teacher who very obviously cares a lot about helping her students (which is unfortunately a rare trait in ICS). The content is dense and very math-heavy but she breaks down everything and explains it all clearly. If you put effort into doing the hw then the tests will not be too bad. The course is difficult but very fair and fun.

We studied a lot from Professor about Database's knowledge (,also Texera!). Professor is an expert in this field, and he can speak everything in this course fluently even without looking at his slides. His slides have concise, clear content for understanding. Professor is also nice, friendly to students. The reviewing day save your self time.

Overall a disorganized course with some issues on HW such as an example that used a different dataset compared to the main problems, with some of my classmates being confused. Midterm and final were not curved either. Gradescope rubrics only say "minor/major error", no explanation on what you got wrong. More zoom office hours would be helpful.

10wk-Summer 2025: Slow responses on Ed Discussion. Lecture slides and HW wasn't enough to help us prepare for exams; many curveball questions, difficulty spikes, and vague info. Splitting method for B tree was not specified on final despite Ed post saying it would be. Good TA who taught the first 2 weeks found lecture slides confusing as well! 1/2
I enjoyed the class a lot but it was really hard. He curves like crazy and the tests are hard. I'm looking forward to taking him for 122C
Loved his class. Really learned a lot. Class is test heavy and grading is unforgiving though.
Run away! Take it with someone else for your own sanity.

65% of the grade is midterm and final, 30% HW (graded, not completion). Exams are extremely difficult when compared to homework and discussion material. Not much practice material at all, felt that lectures did not help us understand how to apply concepts to assignments. Coming from someone who went to class. Slow responses on edstem.

Arrogant professor with heavy workload, quizzes are difficult and projects are time-consuming, if you spent enough time, you can get a good grade. His workload and expectations are exceeding a 4 unit course.

Great course that teaches you a whole lot about full stack web development from frontend to backend database.
The concepts and skills you learn from this course will be beneficial to you even when you go on to the industry.

This has been the most valuable course I've experienced at UCI. For those who are quick to criticize the TAs and the professor due to personal challenges, consider how you would manage learning in a professional setting. Express frustration and cry like a baby to your supervisor because your tasks remain incomplete due to your own issue or what.

Challenging course but very good on learning web development. Projects are VERY HEAVY, more than 1/3 of class turned in proj 2 and 3 late. Online quiz are time demanding (to prevent cheating), barely have enough time to finish them. AWS free tier is a pain to use, simply spending some bucks to upgrade makes life much easier.

Very good lectures, very informative. I did the projects solo, with no experience in web apps. Honestly I wasn't able to complete some of the tasks in time, but I still learned a lot. Class was still less challenging than I thought it'd be. Only downsides of the class is that it is on an old tech stack that modern companies today don't really use.

The projects are a lot of work, but are all very practical in teaching you full-stack development skills, from server to frontend. Beware that you ARE in competition with your peers though, since grades are fairly high, he curves them *down* at the end.

It has 5 projects (84% total) and 3 quiz(5% each). Projects are not hard but you have to spend time on it, so please start soon! Quiz are based on lecture note and project, not hard too. BUT, he may curve DOWN the grade if most of the students did well in class(95% is A and 99% is A+)! So please do extra credits! But you will learn a lot, enjoy!

Prof Li is very good at lecturing and provides easy step-by-step instructions for the entire quarter. Class is extremely organized, and TA's are fast to respond on Piazza. Class requires a lot of time. I spent at least 20 hrs a week on this class for several weeks. You learn a ton in this class, and overall it was worth it and very fun.

Well-organized course, with lots of practical full-stack dev material to be learned. Projects have heavy workload, but you'll learn tons. This past quarter, quizzes had averages in the 60s, so they've gotten harder. Class is curved down a bit at the end, so beware you are up against your peers.

This class was rough at times, but you definitely learn a lot throughout this course. Chen Li is very knowledgeable and projects/quizzes are fair. 5 projects, 3 quizzes. Optional to do projects with a partner, and project time is about 2 weeks each. Really enjoyed this class!

This class is a lot of work, but the work is super important. If you want to be a software engineer you should definitely take this class. This course will give you that full stack experience that you will need for industry. It definitely helped me land an internship!

Very high workload, but one of the most practical project courses at UCI. You learn and apply a ton of full-stack development concepts, from web to mobile, to scaling. Lectures are a bit dry but Li is knowledgeable. Be prepared to write a lot of code.

This class has to be one of the most work-intensive classes I've taken so far, however, you will definitely learn a lot about web dev and how to create an app from scratch. Projects can be done in pairs, 3 quizzes (no midterm/final). Professor Li is a good lecturer and he explains lots of the concepts used in the projects, so definitely attend!
My favorite prof. Well-organized lecture, interesting project!
Easy work, easy A, easy elective!!

Going into this with 0 experience in this type of development, projects were extremely heavy. I recommend starting every project the day its assigned and work on it every day until the due date. DO NOT PROCRASTINATE in this class. Whats nice is the grading rubric is very clear for each project so it provides a checklist to go through.

Unless you have two other people you know can work in a group, avoid this class. Your life will be group projects designed for 3 people. Oh, and  your reward for working your butt off? Well, the entire class worked their butts off too, so be prepared to be curved down. 90%? You mean B+. Skip lectures to work on the projects and to cram for quizzes.
Don't be late otherwise he'll call you out in front of 400 other students

Lectures can be boring, but he really knows the subject matter thoroughly. Listens to feedback from the class well. Projects are daunting but fair, especially if you are learning the material for the first time. Unfortunately he rarely responds on piazza, so you better hope for good TAs. 3 quizzes and no exams, so you must do well on the projects.

He could not speak & explain clearly.  The instructions of homework are extremely confusing.  Midterm was super hard and covered everything, even something not covered in lectures. No sample final for your own good, said Professor Chen, Li I could not believe UCI hired him.  DO AVOID HIM He is just the worst professor on Earth! :(((((((
It's like he's trying to explain Inception

Admittedly, I was scared coming into Professor Li's class, but it honestly was not too bad. The biggest problem with this course is the amount of content that it covers (way too much for 10 weeks), but you will learn, and you will learn a lot. Projects are time-consuming (and at times confusing) but quizzes are easy so long as you attend lecture.

Chen Li's CS122B is hard. Anyone takes this class has to admit that. You have to do tons of work. I spend twenty to thirty hours on the most difficult project. Yes he has Chinese accents, sometimes he is not very clear. BUT, you definitely can learn a lot, really a lot in his class. He will teach you useful things.
nice guy, but seriously he doesn't give clear instructions. i am totally lost and all i get is the worst email replies a professor can give.

The lectures are bad. Every lecture is rushed through as they all have like 60+ slides, which we never have the time to get through. Usually once we get to the last 20 slides, he starts rushing and skips through tons of slides and barely explains others. Lots of self learning will be needed. Noone knows what to study really

Graded on Midterm/Final, 5 HWs, and a group project. Lowest HW dropped. Curve makes it nearly impossible to fail, but still not easy to get an A our quarter. Very math-dense lectures, HW/project more focused on implementation. Tests either based on previous exams, or curved as if they were lol. Great class, learned a lot about ML, would take again.

Not sure why his other reviews are so high. The only thing good about the class was the generous curve at the end. It was his first time teaching so he had to use another professor's notes. His voice and presentational skills doesn't stimulate the interest of other students and by the end of the quarter, only half of the students showed up.

Despite the material being tough, Professor Mandt provides lots of resources and is very responsive online. Homeworks/project are reasonable with the resources and examples that he gives. As long as you put in a couple of hours every week to fully understand the material his class is very stress-free. A very good professor and you learn a lot.

Mandt definitely knows and understands ML. He gives a mathy/theoretical side to everything which can get dense at times but only expects you to know the fundamental ideas and relations. Super responsive to feedback so that's always nice.

The material of this course is quite difficult and Mandt makes sure to cover all of the necessary information in his lectures. Discussions are relevant to the bi-weekly homework and he records his lectures which are invaluable when studying for exams. Mandt really cares for his students and it shows both in person and online on piazza.

This course was very difficult to understand the material. It felt more like a grad course rather than an undergrad course. That being said, the grading was very lenient and curved for high grades. Mandt is very caring and clearly cares about making the experience better for future classes. If you are really interested in ML, he's not a bad choice

Very pleasant attitude and shes decent at teaching the material. However she rarely checks piazza and is slow at posting recorded lectures. Quizzes and Exams are challenging. Make sure you do all the sample problems to do well in the tests.

She was a pretty good teacher and the class is not hard. There was 4 quizzes in the summer session. The zybooks readings were kind of long for no reason and were 15% of our grade. She sometimes assigned them late and made them due in 2 days. Only thing is that she sucks at responding. They dont post solutions on time and don't respond on Piazza.

Her slides are useless and so is her lecture since she reads off the slide and makes up vague examples on the spot during which you won't remember because: 1. You couldn't understand what she said and didn't write it down  2. She doesn't post it later  3. You can't hear her I honestly read the entire chapters and still have no idea what's going on

She explained the subject material very well.  This is good since the book tended to be unclear on a few key topics.  If you look at the previous quizzes and go to discussion, you should do fine in this course.  Everything you need to get a good grade is provided to you and the course requirements are clear.  You can't ask for much more than that.

Awesome professor. She lectures using the slides, but if you are willing to listen, she is really good at explaining everything. I would recommend going to discussion - a lot of the problems covered are very helpful for the exams.
She is one of the worst Professors at UCI.
The class starts out beginner friendly but ramps up in difficulty as you get to tests and projects. It is doable, but always ask questions.

The lectures given are recorded from several quarters ago. Multiple poorly designed quizzes meant to be graded for participation in the middle of a live lecture but are instead graded for correctness. 3 of 5 weeks of class are student presentations, leaving us with a shaky understanding of the concepts at best. Theres a reason her rmp score is a 1

took her for summer session and out of the 5 weeks, 3 were spent doing group presentations. totally ridiculous to have your students teach majority of the class for you. on top of that, she manages to make the most simple concepts confusing. grading was a mess and i'm not even sure what kind of rubric they used. avoid professor in general

Dont know where all of the negativity is coming from. I had her for CS141 and it was great, she spent extra time when asked to explain details, exam was pick 10 of 14 questions (short answer), which made it fairly easy. She will stay after class for any questions/clarifications. I think bad reviewers dont realize class is hard and blame professor.
Alfaro is a nice and easy-going professor. I took the summer class with her. We had take-home exams and participation quizzes.
good luck listening to her brag about her salary and complain about having adhd to explain her bad teaching

She's very bad at doing her job. She had the audacity to brag about her job and how much "bank" she makes. She's a nice person, I just don't think her ways of teaching are appropriate for a serious class like 31.

This professor had bored lecture, and in this lecture just told the content which she assign us for previewing, and it does not have any assist. The sample for the exam has no common place with the real exam paper. The questions for your lab exam would include the extra chapter which you did not learn. All in all, her ics class is a "drop" class.

Read the relevant textbook section(s) before coming to lecture. Then the lecture will answer all your questions. Pay attention when Alfaro's working through examples in class and work them out on your own sheet of paper. If you do this, you will learn SO MUCH. But if you are lazy, you will not - as in any class. Alfaro will not hold your hand.

Alfaro is always inconsistent when it comes to teaching a class. 90% of your grade was based on tests and the other 10% comes from pop quizzes in class. So you technically didn't have to do the labs, but they are great practice/study material for the midterms/final exam. I would avoid her, but she's not THAT bad.
Sometimes you can learn the material and get a good grade. The other times, you may get a bad grade but still learn stuffs. However, with Aflaro,  you can do neither.

Bad professor, not really a surprise that she has the lowest rating of all the UCI computer science professors. She gives a negative attitude in class and tells you that there will be two even three pop quizzes per day in lecture because we're lazy college kids (that are somehow in CS) and that we need to show up. Avoid.

It is so annoying to pay so much per quarter to have this level of teaching! UCI should not allow people like this to teach unless they want their rep to go down.  She is not the first poor teacher I've had here, but really the worst of the worst. Very lazy, totally disorganized, non-responsive,  won't even answer questions in class! Terrible!
Good selection of topics; learned useful concepts for my  CS education

Taught basics, expected absolute mastery of a new language in a week. Followed up by the same thing the week before final. Blamed the students for her own disorganization and claimed no curve. Rudely called out students on a quiz honestly trying. Didn't mention we could have a cheat sheet for midterm and blamed the low scores on us.  Stay away.

She gave "pop quizzes," which were basically attendance  (I bombed almost all of them and got full credit). She expected mastery, but her lectures were disorganized and the assignment specs kept changing up until the deadlines. 5 assignments, very time consuming.  She said no curve because something was wrong with us (stupid). I don't recommend.

Taking her class is a disaster. She did a poor job on teaching, but she blamed every student for "laziness". What did she expect when she taught us to write "hello world" and asked us to implement difficult algorithms on the exam? No curve on the class? Why did she say that when she's mad for some nonsense reason, but not clearly on the syllabus?
Does not explain well and no curves.

This was the most disorganized class I have taken so far at UCI.  She "forgot" to mention to the class that we could use a cheat sheet on the midterm and did nothing to make up for it.  She is unresponsive and uncoordinated with the TA's and graders.  Her homework assignments have vague instructions.  Bless the graders and the TA's poor souls.
Alfaro is one of the worst CS professor in UCI. The other one is Ray Klefstad.
Dont take

One of the worst CS classes I've taken. Midterm average was very low for the whole class and claims that nothing will be curved due to our "laziness". On the day of the midterm she said "Oh by the way, you can use a cheatsheet", which ended up in the class using one page of their notes, and then not getting them back for several weeks.

Other reviews already mention how terrible she is as a lecturer, and I'd like to talk about her exams. The EBNF question on midterm, Prolog and Haskell questions on the final are really hard. I believe most people can figure them out as a homework, but definitely not in an exam, under limited time and so much pressure. Don't take her, she's so bad.

Regular pop quizzes the entire quarter made up 10% of our grade. Not one quiz has been graded/returned, and questions remain unanswered. It took her two lectures to go through one example (on C3), getting lost the entire way. At the end, she said: "But this was easy expect something more difficult for the final." I laughed out loud in class.

Overall, not a very good lecturer. Her lectures are often vague, and do not provide enough information to complete the assignments (as has been the case for her prolog and haskell lectures). Prepare to use stack overflow a lot. She has been behind schedule a lot this quarter, and forgot to tell us we could use a sheet of notes for the midterm.

Lectures don't match the content that you will find on tests and homework. Often times the Lectures will be really far behind schedule, causing cascading delays across due dates. Doesn't seem organized, left up a resubmit dropbox, then deleted it weeks after the due date saying it "wasn't her intention for a regrade", wasting both our and her time.
Be sure to read the reviews for T L Tauro. That's her previous name.

Frequently late to class. Would hardly respond on Piazza and not at all through e-mail. Arrived late to final. Erroneously calculated final grades and had to resubmit them to the registrar, which helped some grades but lowered others. Extremely slow return time on grading (1 assignment of 4 and midterm returned by the final exam).

Had him for 46 and 141, 46 was okay but 141 was a mess. Reading, homework (irl), and lecture quizzes every week all of which had no correlation to each other. Lectures were okay, he was kinda funny, but surface level and usually irrelevant to the quizzes/final. Expects us to learn Lisp and Prolog in 2 weeks. Fail the class if you fail the final.

automatically failing kids if they get below a passing grade on the final is so dismissive of all the work they've put in all quarter. doesn't care for his students at all. dont take unless u have to!!

Every week: Canvas reading quiz + Gradescope lecture quiz + in person proctored homework quiz + Zoom lab + individual programming project!

if (AVG Homework quiz < 60 AND final < 60) return FAIL

Lecture can be accessed on Zoom, good for homework quiz prep.
Final very tough: short on time(75 Qs in 2 hrs) + knowing that I will fail if I score < 60.

I know a lot of the reviewers here r giving bad reviews is only because they failed the class since they couldn't get higher than a 60% on the final. Honest review, will say his passing the final policy is kind bad. HOWEVER, his Final Exam is SUPER SUPER FAIR. All questions were straight forward and from study guide. I crammed in a week and passed
I would give this guy a 0 if i can. Huge ego. Thinks he's better than everyone. His grading policy can smd.

The worst professor to ever exist. Lots of homework and quizzes every week. Has a policy where if you failed the final you automatically fail the class. The loads of assignments he gives out every week are completely a waste if you fail the final.

Lots of assignments and quizzes every week. Huge ego. Gives lots of wrong advice for the software engineering industry. Outdated views on learning and does not respond to Ed. Even my industry mentor believes he has outdated teachings and beliefs. Discourages students with his harsh words. Class content is outdated as well. Avoid at all cost.

There are labs, lecture quizzes, reading quizzes, programming homework, homework quizzes due every single week until week 10. After everyone took finals he made the policy fail finals/homework quiz means you fail the class.

He changed the syllabus on the day the grades were submitted. If you don't pass the final exam, you won't pass the entire course, regardless of how well you did on the previous quizzes, wasting all your efforts throughout the semester. Furthermore, for students he dislikes, he will make you fail the final exam, you won't be able to see your final.

Positive reviews can't be true. The reality is so much more grim, bleak, and anxiety inducing. There is NOTHING good about this prof. Class structure/difficulty needs a MAJOR REWORK. A detriment to mental health, beware. Take care of yourself first. Good luck to SWE majors with this REQUIRED class. The most anxiety I've ever had in my academic life

TL;DR: Lectures too basic, then thrown into DEEP END OF HELL with ANXIETY INDUCING HW; no flexibility, only 1 HW quiz dropped (should allow a HW programming assignment to be dropped), frequent tangents, slow responses on Ed, busywork with reading quizzes + lecture quiz + lab starting week 2, and a self centered high ego and uncaring professor (6/6)

VERY SLOW responses on Ed, professor boasts "post on Ed guys!" yet takes many days to respond during the school week, while assuming people use AI if they don't use Ed. TAs (saving grace) were mostly helpful with long zoom office hours; wish they helped with Ed questions more. Also puts a LEETCODE problem (a HW on its own) in HW4 and HW6. (5/?)

HW quizzes would punish for syntax errors. Understanding concepts/code logic should BE PRIORITY. A programming HW should be dropped, genuinely no flexibility when it comes to CS141. Lectures aren't enough to help with super difficult programming HW, especially LISP/Prolog. Gaslights us into thinking we did not learn from past work/projects (4/?)

Yet we're expected to listen to him ramble about life stories, look up random things, talking about substances? Give me a break with these tangents, wasting time. Attended every lecture and took notes. Treats us like babies over cheating. Maybe if the difficulty of this class was IMPROVED and less HELL INDUCING there wouldn't be any cheating (3/?)

Calls online classes "crack", insults students thinking they don't know how to improve their resume and how they wont get jobs, doesn't care about the well being of students (awful busywork and anxiety inducing HW. HW4, 5, and 7 are awful; HW7 should be abolished, worst one ever), tries to diminsh value of students' past work/projects. (2/?)

Fall 2025: HIGH EGO AND SELF CENTERED, who drowns you in the WORST busywork in the horror called the massive time sink that will take away time from your other classes and MENTAL HEALTH. I don't care if you're a pro LISP programmer; teach the material at hand IN DEPTH THAT IS SUFFICENT to ease the SUFFERING of the anxiety inducing homework. (1/?)

professor clearly emphasizes the core concepts of each programming language which covers java, C/C++, lisp, and prolog. This is assessed each week by a reading quiz, post-lecture quiz, coding assignment, lab, and in-lecture written quiz. There is a last extra credit project where you can program another new language of an existing coding assignment

Pros: You'll learn Lisp and Prolog. Professor has interesting life stories though and is hilarious. Labs are required and you get to choose between different TA time slots
Cons: Lots of homework assignments that are time consuming. 3 Quizzes a week with 1 of them in person. You won't have free time! Average grade on the final was 65% before curve.

there is a huge workload. quiz due Monday, lab and lecture quiz due tuesday, homework code and hw questions due Wednesday, quiz thursday . and then rinse and repeat for 10 weeks straight. so much work in comparison to the other classes. learn many languages and 2 languages were extremely difficult to learned.

Super engaging professor, he really makes you care about the course content and want to show up to class. If you're interested in the material and want to learn, he will help you learn more than almost any other professor at UCI. Weekly in-person homework quizzes, weekly online reading & lecture quizzes (easy), and required lab work, only a final.

He has good lectures so I'll give him that. But the fact that there are 3 quizzes (one in person) and a long homework every week is terrible. I feel like I'm taking a lower-div course again when this is an upper-div course. I don't recommend taking this course unless you want to be treated like an underclassmen or this class is required.

3 quizzes every week (one for reading, lecture, and homework). The only thing this class helps you with is recursion, but you can do master that in CS161 too. Honestly, this class isn't worth taking because the amount of time required on these long homeworks and mandatory readings take away time for leetcode and job applications. Waste of time.

Overall a doable class. Grades were returned relatively regularly but that's probably because of good TAs. Lectures aren't mandatory, discussions are. There are 3 quizzes & hw due every week. Don't take it with other project courses. Professor tries to make the class engaging but the workload is so heavy. Few concepts were fun, but not worth.

Depends on your TA. Klefstead doesn't teach the class LOL the TA does. Luckily the TA did an amazing job (Alexander Iskander). Really responsive on Piazza, knows his stuff, and goes over a lot of the HW material over lecture (Klefstead will try to pitch in but he doesn't really know what he's talking about)

Thanks, Alex, he is the best TA, Ph.D. Alex should teach this class.
TA teaches most of this class, and the majority of the answer in the piazza is by TA.
This class grade depends on TA. The class is perfect and it takes about 20 hours per week for coding and studying. I do learn a lot from Alex.

Really terrible and unprepared professor. This is my second time taking him. Previously I took him for Advanced C++ and figured it was bad because the course was brand new. Doesn't respond to emails and is just a slack person in general. His idea of engaging projects is filling out an outline of a program and giving it to students.

It is unacceptable to FORGET to submit our final grades. This professor really does not care about the students. He gets very distracted during lectures and looks up random stuff during class. His homework assignments are not too bad except for the last one. I would not take his class again and neither should you.
HIs lectures are both funny and insightful, but the class organization is a mess. You get grades back way late and Piazza questions are answered if the responsible TAs are nice (half of them were).

Klefstad is organized but theres a LOT of work. 3 quizzes PER WEEK. Each assignment is in a different programming language. Lisp and Prolog are a lot of fun. Start them early though bc some of the hw questions are pretty hard. Very responsive on Piazza. Time consuming class but you learn a lot.

This class is so unorganized. He doesn't want you to send emails with questions, and his TAs are equally as unresponsive. The homework is often ambiguous, although not hard if you understand what you're doing. Piazza posts are often ignored for 6+ days and you're pretty much on your own. Overall, a lazy, uncaring, and awful professor. Avoid him.

The content isn't hard, but the disorganization in the class makes it significantly harder. Don't believe him when he says he "cares about your education". Don't expect any questions regarding assignments to be answered.

The biggest blocker to your class will be his disorganization and him blatantly not caring about the class. Be ready for last minute changes to assignments and projects. He's is not responsive at all to emails, nor piazza, and will berate you in OH for asking stupid questions. This class is completely carried by the TA's.

He is a very nice guy and really has a passion for teaching, it just doesnt fit the way I learn. I can tell he is putting effort into his lectures and he knows his stuff but its just too casual for me. There isnt enough substance in the lectures to be worthwhile for me, at least for this class. Just read the book. he is oddly motivational at least.
Absolute trash class with insane amounts of work. Assignments use tools that are not taught in class.

funny guy, fun lectures, very accomodating, office hours are helpful, homework is hardddd af which is where i think most kids complain about, but they're not worth alot so even if u miss some pts i think ur good, quizzes and final are pretty easy, time consuming class for sure
worst professor ever

He became one of my FAVORITE professors, so hilarious. Homework is definitely difficult, but doable. Quizzes every week which sucks but made the final really easy since I was forced to learn. His office hours not alot of people go, but he looks at your code and helps you debug it. He also extended deadlines like 3 times when people asked. 10/10

Funny guy, but the workload is pretty heavy. There is a spike in difficulty in the middle of the quarter as you tackle LISP and PROLOG assignments. Three weekly quizzes and a consistently tough homework assignment makes this class challenging, but they aren't worth much of your grade-- feel free to skip the harder ones if you just want to pass.

One of the most inspiring professors in the CS department. They way he organizes the classes doesn't make them easy, and you will hurt your grade if you don't take the work seriously. but you'll get an excellent opportunity to learn from him. He is a great teacher and he really cares about your learning, just not an easy professor.

This class was very unorganized from the start. Initially we were supposed to have 10 Projects (1 per week) along with mini Lecture Activity assignments (1 per week as well). No midterms/no final. Our current proj was so poorly written that I'm on RMP writing this review. Save your grade and time, do not even consider taking this course..

This man doesn't give any instructions. I got a 99% in ICS 45C and am taking this class P/NP. Not because it's intellectually hard. This professor gives the most ambitious guidelines and uses an autograder that gives you all or nothing. Very unresponsive on piazza. Advertised this course as teaching advanced concepts, but didn't even teach.

Really funny and active professor. You can't NOT pay attention in his class, the way he teaches. Imagine the "Double Dream Feet" guy teaching you about v-tables. You do have to go to each and every lecture, because there are quizzes at each one, and he dropped huge homework hints in lecture before the due dates. Great prof with a bad rap from 122B.

Happily graduated with nothing but bad things to say about klefstad and his classes. Definitely avoid him if you can. His classes are all poorly organized and very intense. His 122b was by far worst experience I've had at UCI. Nobody knew how grading worked or how to do the assignments because TAs (poorly) ran the entire class.
worst professor ever. never going to take any of his classes again. very mean and unorganized

klefstad was alright for 45c but 122b was definitely too big of a jump for him. the class was a mess. i would have been more understanding if they had handled the problems better. the TAs and professor should have lowered the insane workload once they realized how many mistakes were in all of their documentation/instructions
worst class i took at uci
Nope Just say no. Disorganized and he doesn't even teach, all the teaching is done by TAs. Maybe his other classes are good but not this.

In one of the first lectures he said that "we're not so smart because anybody can get into UC Irvine". He proceeded to try teaching a class in which he knew NONE of the material, the TAs did everything and made the class impossibly hard/unorganized. News flash: TAs are not yet equipped to run a class. Horrible experience

Your grade is solely decided by your ability to do well in a horrid game of random luck, chance, and confusion. Clear instructions? Forget about it. Clear grading criteria? In your dreams. Klefstad talking about how amazing of an instructor he is? Just about the only thing you can count on. JUST SAY NO

I came into this class having extensive experience making web apps using the exact libraries taught in this class, yet I still struggle because the HWs have many mistakes and are too ambitious for the time given to complete them. Can't imagine what those with no experience are going through. Horrible class and professor
one in every 2 years there is a horrifying professor. I was pretty much due. lol
If you like having no social life, learning very little, and being talked down to, take a class with this man. Otherwise, do yourself a favor and pick someone else

The class is run in too disorganized of a manner for you to actually learn anything about WebDev. You can easily learn SQL and Java web development by doing your own project. There is nothing complex about the material in this class, it's just repetitive busywork with poor directions, many ambiguities, and strict grading requirements.

All the things said about this class is true, changing hw docs, wacky grading scheme, run by TAs, 20+ hour weeks. But in light of all this, you do get to work on a pretty substantial project and peek at industry level web dev. This class was a real test to time management. You will get frustrated but I think its worth the challenge.
literally the worst experience of my life

Klefstad oesn't know how to webdev, class is run by TAs, terrible management and unclear assignments even on the day it's due. Starting early means you get punished with changing requirements. Workload is incredibly heavy, I don't think I even have a life at this point. Worst class I've ever had the displeasure of taking here at UCI.

Insane workload. make 2 homework assignments due at the same week. You can only get 80% of total grade even if you attended every lectures and got 100% on every hw, cause he has his "optional credits" that are not really optional

Klefstad has TAs write up the assignments with MANY errors/ambiguities in them. You have to stalk Piazza to get frequent changes and updates. I've never seen a Piazza with so much confusion. HWs are often changed the day before they're due because of mistakes, so can't start early. Horrible nightmarish class and Klefstad is clueless about web dev.

He has no idea what he's doing. The TAs completely run this class, writing assignments, creating/running unit tests, etc. Klefstad forces participation in lectures he doesn't even know the subject matter on. Just a talking babble head flaunting his life and nothing more
Just say NO!!!!
Just don't.

I had Klefstad when he briefly taught at UC Riverside. One thing that struck me was how his classes were completely irrelevant to the subject matter. He would, for examples, give lectures about his vacations and snorkeling adventures.
Unqualified to teach upper div CS courses

Dear transfer students. Avoid this professor at all costs coming in. My transfer friends were flustered with Klefs hw and quizzes after week 3. They knew the material but this professor kept throwing curve balls, making them look adrift. I did well with luck from other students and at a huge cost of my sleep and diet. I learned very hard on my own.

Comments here are mostly true. I could relate to many of the negative comments because they go into detail. The positive comments dont go into detail about the great things, so its obvious that they dont have much to back up their claims.
The 3rd worst professor/teacher. Thats like a 3 / 60 since elementary to university. Save yourself some grief!

I did not know anyone in class so understanding the material was a serious challenge. Many times I thought you needed insider information to understand. Don't attend class because he wastes your time and put the travel and class time as extra time on your assignments. Be early for lab and have all your questions prepared because it was disorganized

Disorganized mess of a class. I think this is his first quarter teaching 122B, but i doubt it will improve much knowing Klefstad. I've taken 141 with him as well and hated that. Mandatory attendance in a PROJECT course is the cherry on top. Klefstad loves to lecture about how amazing he is more than he likes to explain material. Avoid avoid avoid

Feeling discouraged. Participated, went to lab every week, and wrote notes in pencil. I followed his directions but left the course being more confused. The only clear thing I learned was, I'm clearly not taking his classes ever again.

I dont know what happened to him Winter quarter. Its if there was a jekyll and hyde transformation. There are serious polar opposite reviews about him from previous quarters, but mine wasnt on the positive side. Search ray klefstad about the girl who walked in the class on search engine to read details.

Many of the other comments are about 88% true. The very positive comments are peculiar because I want them to be right, but I cannot see what they see. I dont recommend this professor for anyone. His outgoing personality makes you want to believe in the material, but he doesnt effectively prepare us. Which is a disaster. Good luck if you have him
Not worth it.

Don't take him. Beware of confusing assignments and uncoordinated lectures. This course was made overly difficult, not because of the material, but because he wasn't to the point and deviated far for too long. The amount of time wasted from off topics is time he substitutes away from lecture (implementation examples). So mostly vocab. Good luck...

prof makes fun of other majors, vague hw instructions, and highly disorganized. Found myself being 100% attentive during lecture and walking out realizing I didn't learn anything that can be applied to hw. learned a lot, but not because of his teaching. bad prof, great class. self study and ask questions to assistants in discussion

Klefstad is the worst professor I've taken at UCI. Narcissistic, arrogant, and clueless to the real world. Wastes lecture time talking about his hobbies and assigns ambiguous homework written by the TA's in not-great English. Will never take again.

Klefstad's classes are always a mess. Lectures are off-topic and instead about his life, HW specs unclear etc. He can't seem to find a way to organize things clearly, and it causes this class to be way more confusing than it needs to be. Quizzes and final are fair at least. HW is annoying cuz vague, but are graded easy due to the his"report" system

Horrible horrible horrible horrible horrible experience. Probably my least favorite class I've taken at UCI. There is an obvious disconnect between the test/HW-makers and the material presented in class, because there is absolutely no relation at all. Yet, we're expected to sit in lecture and listen to bad jokes for 45 minutes? Give me a break

Trash teacher. He doesn't actually teach the material on the homework. Quizzes usually reflect material from the homework. Goes on too many side tangents and likes to call out students for distracting him when really he's making a big fuss out of nothing and making the situation worse. Definitely do not take if possible.

An essential characteristic of a good software engineer, let alone a CS lecturer is COMMUNICATION. Alhough Klefstad is passionate, his ability to lecture on-topic and articulate clear HW specs is lacking (vague docs, wants you to read his mind). If he had this skill, the difficulty of this class would be justified (you learn a lot, but not from him

Klefstad is very passionate, which makes it hard for me to critique him, but i will anyway. Coding by hand is not something I've done since freshman CS classes and i'm not a fan of this practicing this pointless skill. There's also an excessive workload with weekly quizzes and HWs that are on material which Klefstad himself is unable to understand.

Very misleading. His homeworks are ideal to learn, but how he presents them to you is troublesome. Balancing this class will seriously stagger your success or performance in other courses. Most of your time isnt programming, its comprehending his assignments and grading criteria.

4.0s only is back Absolutely amazing class. These lectures were inspiring, and the homework was challenging, but fun. The content on the quiz was always closely related to the previous homework, allowing me to snag an easy A+ (curve). I'm so happy I took this class. I will never forget the invaluable concepts Klefstad passed down to me.

You are coding "blindfolded". You'll feel obligated to intuitively learn from expression & able to code it without concretely referencing it. I used to like the course until I asked for mercy early on & left empty-handed. If you have to suffer: HW4 & so on, switch into turbo, especially HW5, 7, 8-9 Then post here for another poor soul to do better.

It's already been said. Klefstad's quite arrogant, doesn't really teach the CS141 material to a level where it is easily transferable to his assignments or his tests---basically you learn it on your own. His lectures are 90% background information or history and 10% actual relevant code/practices needed for his impossible assignments.

The horror stories about this class are true. Taking this class ended up being a disaster and one of my most challenging experiences at UCI. Don't take my word for it, search the "klefstad manifesto" on reddit to see what others had to say.

Klefstad is pretty hilarious. But you will struggle in this class if you aren't a VERY strong programmer. Klefstad himself is unable to solve the problems he assigns. In my opinion, that should be a minimum requirement for a problem to be included anywhere in the course: the professor should be able to solve it.

Saying Klefstad wastes lecture time is an understatement. Weekly quizzes/HWs are excessive and are designed by TAs which are completely disconnected from the small bit of material covered in class. Quizzes require rigorous coding-by-hand, even the TAs struggled to solve the problems in lab. Klefstad was even further from being able to solve them.

Klefstad is more polarizing than most profs, but all things considered I think he's quite good. It's not difficult to get an A in his classes if you put the effort in. The usual complaint about him is that he doesn't teach to the HW in the lectures, and expects students to be able to look up documentation on their own (not unreasonable imo).

I really liked this class. It had a lot of challenging homework. Yicong was super nice and helpful, and Klefstad was really responsive in office hours. I think the class made it difficult for the staff to help, because everyone just spammed Piazza. Take this class if you really like programming languages & if you like challenging yourself. :)
The homework and quizzes are pretty easy. The test had a few errors on it. I didn't like the lectures. Anyone with ok programming ability could get through the homework/quizzes just fine.

Quizzes are fine. He preps you for those. What he doesn't prep you for is the homework you'll spend your life doing from weeks 3 to 8. If not for Yicong (TA) on piazza, this class would have been a massive disaster. Can be entertaining in lecture, but half the stuff he says is an unrelated opinion. Doesn't teach you much, you learn from the hw

This class is not for the faint of heart. You need to work on your assignments from day 1 because some of the material won't be apparent until some time after. You must be on piazza to pass because his curriculum changes, often. His homework changes, but updates are only on piazza. Search the "klefstad manifesto" to learn more from other students.

Currently taking him. So far its a mix. He's not bad; but I haven't seen anyone better. Without a doubt, you will learn. Friends aren't doing so well, I only hear the bad end of it. I'm actively listening and learning w/out the stigma of the grade. You'll feel like you're for Trump *cough* Klefstad, or not. This was a consuming class most definite.

Only, and I mean ONLY, take this class if you are a strong independent learner (assume you don't have a professor). His assignments are long and extraordinary. He won't teach you anything but vocabulary. As for learning implementation, you are on your own to figure it out. The first 3 assignments are a cake; but the rest you have been warned.

Study his slides & homework , you still will not do well after 3rd quiz. Used to structure and clear grading criteria? He will grade you based on your talent. The homework will not prepare you. You need to look deeper and nitpick the language of topic (if you can finish the hw on time). Only take if you want a challenge & don't mind a lower gpa.

Klef doesn't teach well. It is hit or miss. He is knowledgeable, and I wish so much that he would actually just talk about the material at hand, and give more direction on the HW. His instructions are unclear, HW can be frustrating, and grading questionable. Even more, this quarter for our class, he doesn't have office hours, because screw students

Consistently sends out homework with typos and vague directions. Barely made it through 3 or 4 of the slides each lecture as he was too busy heckling students coming in late or talking about his life.

He's a very enthusiastic, engaging professor in his lectures, and entertaining. Slides aren't the best/most clear, so overall teaching is just OK. Homework started out fine but as the course went on became very vague due to poor instructions and clarity. Quizzes are fair as he typically tells the topics beforehand.

Quizzes are a major part of your grade, and they are usually a more challenging version of one of the questions on the homework. There is homework due every week and it's usually 7+ hours of work (unless you're a super programmer in Java, C++, Lisp, and Prolog) instructions are vague (he want's you to read his mind).Start the homework early!

Klefstad is unique. He hates Python, and he loves C. He wants everyone to master C. It's painful, because C is a low level language. He spends a lot of time in class to talks about his life and tries to be cool and fun. Some students enjoy this, but some think it's totally a waste of time. It's up to you to like or hate him, but he is a good guy.

Great person, great sense of humor, and seems he has an awesome life. Lectures were interesting at times but not helpful; It's like he would teach us 1+12 and send us home to derive the mass of an electron using strong induction and relativity laws. However, if you've taken way more classes than ICS 33, it's an easy A with some self-teaching.

V is a nice professor. However, the entire class is lecture karaoke. She reads off slides (total of ~400) the entire quarter. The slides are so vague though that it's recommended to listen to her lectures, but you WILL space out. Attendance not required. One midterm (85% avg) & final (75% avg). 3 (not fun) group coding assignments. 4 Simple HWs.

Ven is a caring professor who gives very good, detailed lectures. She is very flexible and knowledgeable. HW's are doable through following lecture, textbook, and other online resources. Midterm and final are similar to HW's. There is a short coding project at the last half, and shouldn't take more than 2 days.

Professor Ven is very informative, has good lectures, and is sympathetic with her students. The midterm can be well studied from the lectures notes and homework. The homeworks take anywhere from 1-3 hours depending on your prior knowledge of the material. Class is similar to ICS 53. One coding project at the 2nd half of the class.

She is a nice lady, but that's about as good as it gets for this review. This class was very disorganized. The TAs made a complete mess of the "project." If you really want to learn OS, I would hold out for another professor.

She is a very strong lecturer and explains the concepts very well. The grading is all around fair and there is nothing unreasonable. The material on the midterm and final are covered well by the professor and the homeworks.

Pretty good professor. Lectures are clear and and she explains concepts pretty well, at a good pace. Concept heavy class, only one programming assignment. Exams are fair and heavily based on the HW and slides.

Of the two professors, Professor V is perhaps the more outgoing and relatable one. This course is tough; there are lots of definitions and concepts covered during lecture, and it is unclear as to which topics are most important. In fact, exam questions may bring up trivial concepts only lightly touched upon during the course, if at all.

Very dense lectures with a lot of theory but not tested on most of it. 1 midterm and final project, midterm wasn't too bad and the group project + report are very straightforward. The assignments weren't too bad but you have to self-teach because he doesn't go over any code in class. Pretty similar to CS 178
Great Explainer and fairly easy exam. Avg score for midterm is 80%
Love this guy

Some of the sample exam problems weren't covered directly in the lectures, and parts of the programming HW weren't either, so I ended up relying more on documentation & discussion material. Professor is definitely passionate and knowledgeable in machine learning, but he rushed the material nearing the end. The material is difficult, but he curves.

Very smart guy. Clas was 80% content from CS 178 and 20% applications to biology. No homework, just a final class project. Midterm was difficult but he curved generously. I'd recommend experience in programming and ML before taking this class. Lectures were pretty math heavy but he does a good job of slowing down/reviewing concepts.
The worst experience

AI project class, focused on deep learning in the quarter I took. I found the class inspiring. The lectures mainly covered material on convolutional net and its application in computer vision. The assignments are challenging, but rewarding in the end. My main concern is the organization. The teaching staff was late in grading assignments.

Got my assignment's score back during finals week, but the problem only started here. 1) They contradicted themselves and took points off for not completing what is not required to. 2) They basically never reply to piazza or email, and they say they are busy. 3) Took them 8WK to grade my hw, I am legit worried when I'm going to get my project grade

After taking this course, I completely lost interest in deep learning. Extremely unorganized class. The professor basically taught nothing throughout the entire quarter. The project is "here is a general topic go do it if you don't know how to do it google it" type of project. Assignment grades came out 5 days before class ends. etc. advice: AAAC

Be prepared here to learn everything here by yourself here. Everything here in this class here is a copy from Stanford CS231n here . The professor here is not clear with his lecture here and I wouldn't recommend to go to lectures here. Definitely start hw early here cuz it's gonna take you a long time here to finish here.

Professor Xie is a fantastic teacher, probably one of the best I've had at UCI.   He made a difficult subject easy to understand. I especially liked the way he explained the material and made it easy to follow. I would definitely recommend the course to other students.

Worst professor I've had at UCI. Provided no information on the final projects outside of class. On the syllabus he says to ask him questions on Piazza instead of email, yet he doesn't answer questions on Piazza. Didn't even bother to email out information on the final project.

She is a nice person. It is so nice to go to her office hour and get connected to her. 

Her lecture is intense, and she explains the idea very well (sometimes may be a bit disorganized, as she would jump back to a same concept a week later).

The lectures are mostly theoretical, and the assignments are code-based (needed func. will be provided)

Gave practice exams that had nothing to do with the real exam. Exams also had formulas and problems that were never taught or properly covered during class or assignments. At most they were lightly mentioned in passing. Lectures were useless, straight up slideshow puppet. ALSO PROMISED CURVE ON EDDISCUSSION AND GAVE NO CURVE.

Very little feedback. Almost all "learning" is through completing jupyter notebook assignments and reading docs to get through them.

I honestly don't even know what she is saying half the time during lecture. She thinks she is making the content more digestible but in reality she is not really even teaching it. Yet she complains about attendance.

Unable to choose any tags from Rate My Professor since they seemed too positive for her. Lectures are simple, covering basic material with minimal explanation—mostly just skimming through slides. Teaching quality is low despite high expectations.
Lecture is not bad but hard exam. Can't believe she just let us calculate MSE without any formula.

Poor course structure and she does not like answering questions during class because she has lots of slides. Students do not receive feedback on points lost for assignments. Nobody attends discussions because they don't help, so she decided to withhold necessary information to force attendance. Doesn't answer questions outside of office hours.

I think Nadia is a caring and genuine person, but the lecture material is very vague. Most of the given resources we're also not very helpful as they were outdated in terms of what topics it covered. Overall Nadia is chill, but after this class, I wished I took Ihler instead.
Super chill person, but the lecture slides' content is disorganized and vague. HW is based on using matplotlib and other tools such as sci-kit learn.
Five days before finals week she come up with this 10 page memo we had to do for our projects, but was never mentioned...
She used 8 weeks to talk about github and organizing

W24. Some lecture participation. 3 HW & final project based on 2021 IEEE GRSS DSE (diff each quarter -> disorganized). They build on each other: only HW1 was solo, rest group work. Based on the final project, make poster (cost about $45), presentation slides, & 8+ page paper. No grades on Canvas until grades deadline. Not really active on discord.

Homework instructions are somewhat confusing and unclear, topic changes quarterly. Mostly group work, so find a good group! She is really nice, caring and very flexible though, course staffs were very attentive and helpful.

attendance sometimes mandatory (miro boards for participation)
started covering content week 5, project is supposed to be done in 3 weeks
projects - teams of 4, topic changes every quarter -> new assignments created which leads to unclear instructions with mistakes, very difficult hw1
assignments are self learn
course discord, staff are helpful
Homeworks are confusing, lectures are mostly group activities.

Not a huge fan of classes where 100% of the course grade is dictated by test scores, but ultimately the grading scale makes it easy to get a good grade. Some of the tests really had me stressing, but then I didn't even have to take the final and got an A+. I can't learn anything via lecture, so I really did appreciate the lecture optional format.

63% got an A- or above this time. He doesn't curve, but imo that makes it fairer. 
Do the diagnostic exams (IMPORTANT) and PSETS. I learned a lot in this class as a newcomer to algos. 
My only complaint is that diagnostics and solutions "like exams" should be posted a bit sooner. Only 1.5 days to do the diagnostic, though it is short.

You actually learn in this class. Very few assignments. 95% of your grade is composed of your test performance, however his tests are incredibly fair in terms of difficulty. Do your homework and you will be fine.

Lectures well on the concepts, the practice if mainly up to your own time with the problem sets and during the discussion sections. There are short warmups before each lecture, which you have to do some basic thinking. I think the warmups could go more in depth, but overall, it's a class that broadened my way of problem solving.

Great professor.  UCI is lucky to have him.  He is the goat. I learned a lot from his class, he cares about his students,  and truly wants to help them succeed.  Also, tells very corny jokes. His girlfriend is cute too, I spotted them this summer,  in Newport Beach getting ice cream.
definently a professor. definently not a good one. thats for sure. 100% avoid

He literally ruined my life. I shiver in fear every time i see him. I saw him at utc over the summer and almost had a heart attack. Thought he would break into rambling about wearing pink on wednesdays or about walking 10 miles to the beach. Terrifying man.
honestly not a fan
Kind of messed up how badly some people take a bad grade. There is really no need to spread lies and misinformation due to your failure to preform well
he is my sunshine :))))
He almost makes me forget about the crippling student debt. Truly an amazing professor
The Lebron James of UCI professors. Klefstad is Micheal Jorfraud 😒

Not only have you changed the game of basketball and the world forever, but you've eternally changed my world. And now you're getting older, but still the goat, my goat. I love you pookie bear, my glorious king, Shindler☺️♥️🫶🏻

I just wanted you to return home. Then allas, you did, my sweet baby boy came home and I rejoiced. 2015 was a hard year for us baby, but in 2016 you made history happen. You came back from 3-1 and I couldn't believe it. I was crying, bawling even, and I heard my glorious king exclaim these words, "UCI, THIS IS FOR YOU!"

You have given me so much joy, and heartbreak over the years. I remember when you first left USC and its like my heart got broken into a million pieces. But a tear still fell from my right eye when I watched you win your first tenure in UCI, because deep down, my glorious king deserved it.

You had a rough childhood, but you never gave up hope. You are even amazing off the clasroom, you're a great husband and father, sometimes I even call you dad. I forvever dread and weep, thinking of the day you will one day retire. I would sacrifice my own life it were the only thing that could put a smile on your beautiful face.

Boy oh boy where do I even begin. Shindler... honey, my pookie bear. I have loved you ever since I first laid eyes on you. The way you explain dynamic progamming. Your funny jokes, charismatic smile, and that wonderful sense of humor. I would do anything for you. I wish it were possible to freeze time so I would never have to watch you retire.
Stop review bombing the GOAT professor. Get a life
bad.. so bad i have no words
you just lost the game
way to easy. his class is a joke. i fear uci students.... may not be the sharpest tools in the shed

Prof. Shindler is amazing. His lectures are very entertaining and he teaches well. Exams are well-graded, if you do well on midterms, you don't need to take the final! His lectures were at 8 AM, if you don't go it's okay, go to discussions for sure. The class was just very test-heavy, no HW besides 10 min warm-ups twice a week.

Extremely overrated instructor. Lacks effective teaching skills. The material itself isn't challenging, but poor instruction made it harder to grasp. The only relief was successfully completing the course—definitely won't be taking any classes with this professor again.
People only hype him up because he's hot.
One of the hardest classes I taken so far. His teaching style is very difficult to follow and most of the material is self taught. The discussions are more useful than the lectures itself.

I think most people think the class is hard and put the blame on him. He really does try to get his students to understand the course content properly. I really like him and planning on taking 162 with him next year!
This is a very hard course!
Lecture slides are to help him remember what to teach instead of helping students.
I am so stressed about this class. A lot of the teaching can be improved (I know many won't agree but this is the truth).

this class is literally ruining my life single handedly 
i have constant panic attacks every single time i study for it
dont take it w schindler
sucky overall
He is so handsome and funny. Taking this class is like going to a comedy show while learning a lot! Its like your not even in class and you look forward to it everyday.

One of my favorite classes so far. Prof Shindler is the best lecturer I've had in my university career and I am sad I will no longer be able to take any more classes with him. I would recommend this class to anyone interested in computer science theory.

Easily my favorite class so far at UCI. He has made me love this sort of material and I have chosen my specialization based on my experience with him as my professor. GO TO OFFICE HOURS. If you do the practice problems with the TAs or tutors, you will greatly solidify your understanding of the content and its applications.

Difficult subject material is unavoidable, but Prof. Shindler is definitely passionate about teaching and helping his students succeed. Super chill guy, tries to keep lectures fun by cracking jokes, and gracefully accepts feedback/criticisms. He's not afraid to be corrected which is really great.

He's an incredible prof, had him for 46 and 161. Great at making analogies that students can understand. Don't be frightened by the final exam weight, you can cover some or all of the pts using midterm scores. Def do the problem sets (they're usually funny) and Goodrich/Erickson textbook questions, they make the class so much easier.

Schindler is a great lecturer that genuinely cares for his students - very fun person overall. Schindler treats 162 more chill than his other courses. Exams sometimes felt like solving puzzles (a good or bad thing depending if you like brain/logic puzzles), but there's PLENTIFUL practice exercises & lenient (fair) grading. Loved the prof's energy!

Shindler is a wonderful professor; he is great at lecturing and the course topic is highly interesting if you're into theoretical topics. Homework is a good amount of your grade, but is graded leniently and isn't too time consuming. Help from either the TA's or Shindler is always accessible. Attending discussion is vital to prepare for tests.

Easily the best class at UCI. Graded by four exams and biweekly homework - final skippable if you do well on the final question on each exam. Excellent lectures and discussions. Excellent side material to learn better. Really great class culture and a strong effort to connect to students. Very important and super cool material for CS. Shindler=GOAT

Awesome upper div CS class. Interesting material, and Shindler clearly cares about his students' success. The material can be difficult to digest at times, but grading is generous. If you study/do homework/practice exams, you'll do well.

Regarding Shindler's classes, you get back what you put in. 

In both 46 and 161, I had to excessively try to keep up and perform well in both classes, however, I argue that Shindler supplies you with a quality of knowledge that makes it all worth it. 

Highly recommend him if you are up for the challenge. Do not recommend him if you want it easy.

Honestly one of the hardest class I ever took at UCI. I did manage to get an A however, you practically have to sell your soul for this class if you want an A. Very hard to understand lectures that is hard to understand later if you skip lectures in person. Projects are extremely difficult and takes days to finish. Just don't expect any free time.

Thankfully, 161 was not as bad as 46 with Shindler. Nevertheless, the concepts (divide & conquer, dynamic programming, greedy) were very difficult and often I left lecture being lost the whole time. I had a great TA for discussion that helped me understand these concepts. Mike's lectures were engaging and I liked the class format. Do not skip class
This man single handedly carries the entire CS department

Tough class, but he does great job explaining everything. Lectures are very important. I didn't like that we didn't write actual code, bc sometimes it is difficult to translate an algorithm into code, but you get a great understanding of algorithms taught in this course. Grading criteria benefits student. No hurt final. Also, his lectures are fun
The homework doesn't help much with grade as most grade comes from the test. In order to do well you basically have to attend the lectures but the lectures are a bit boring

I really enjoyed having Shindler as a prof. I found his 46 class very difficult and stressful. His 161 class was a continuation of 46 but I liked 161 way more (no projects, mainly conceptual). Majority of grade is tests- 3 tests (for each topic), optional final only to boost grade, some conceptual homework. Highly recommend for 161.

3 tests and a final but the final can only boost your grade. Homework is pretty hard as it's all conceptual. He's a great lecturer but doesn't explain certain things in detail during lecture. You'll have a better chance talking to him 1 on 1 and understanding better. Although lectures are hard to connect to the exam material.
Always goes on tangents during lecture and homework is not worth anything compared to exams
Most of grade only comes from exams

Lectures for this course are relatively interesting. But the grading is horrible because grading rubric/criteria is very unclear on free response questions for the exams. Hard to reach the professor as well

Prof. Shindler is one of my favorites for upper div CS. Lectures are good, grading was very generous and you get multiple chances to demonstrate you know a topic. I really enjoyed this class, and professor Shindler is great!

After taking CS161 with him, I feel that I had to do this. He is one of the best prof in UCI and care a lot about students. Lots of homework indeed, but in exchange you can skip final exam if you do well in three topic exams. The lectures are not mandatory and recorded. There will be a curve (or adjusting the cut-point) in the end of the quarter.

By far the best professor I have taken at UCI. Genuinely cares for his students and is extremely patient with his explanations. He made me not fear asking questions In class and made sure we understood. Lectures can be hard to follow but overall a great professor.

Nice and caring, but lecturing skills aren't great. Goes off on tangents every couple of minutes, so it can be difficult to follow his train of thought. Explanations are VERBOSE. Instead of taking 30 sec to draw a picture, he'll spend 4 minutes re-explaining a concept. And his lectures, purposely, are not detailed. Great person though
Shindler is an amazing prof. He really cares about his students and is always willing to help. He responds very quickly to questions and is very funny. You will learn a ton!

A real gem. He's famous because he's such a good professor. Good at teaching and good at making students feel comfortable to learn. This class was hard but I got through it because of him and learned a lot. Homework problems count for grade but they help you learn. Quizzes exactly like the practice so do them and you will succeed. He's a great prof

He is great. CS161 is one of the hardest classes because algorithms are hard. But Shindler's lectures make the experience great. He is good at explaining and will stop to explain until you understand if you're lost. He cares a lot about students learning and succeeding. His quizzes reflect the practice quizzes and homework. TAKE his class.

Overall a good professor. Extremely clear grading criteria, clearly cares about his students and the way how the class is structured, and makes easy jokes. His lectures and lecture slides are a bit lacking though -- sometimes concepts are not explained in an easy manner, and his analogies makes things more confusing. Generous on grading!
Most enthusiastic CS professor I've had so far. Not much homework, but it can be challenging.
Shindler is a nice guy but this class was not great. He consistently does not stay on topic for his lectures and in a 50 min lecture provides 10 min of actual content and 40 min of fluff.

Quizzes are extremely similar to the reinforcement exercises & problem sets. Ask questions on Piazza. Don't expect your question to be answered in lecture/discussion, Shindler goes on 30 tangents lmao. Final project is conceptually hard, if you want above 80% START EARLY. No final exam for online. Projects 1, 2, Final all in C++ in the VM.

Take Dillencourt instead of him. This guy only knows how his answer works, but if you provide another algorithm, he would give you 0 score. Also, he won't give out the test case of the project, so basically you don't know what's wrong with you algorithm.

Shindler seems to care about his students; he answers questions in Zoom office hours (often staying overtime), and his lectures were fairly clear and had funny moments. However, the class was a bit disorganized. Grades took a long time to come out, the grading criteria was sometimes unclear, and one of the quizzes had part of the questions missing.

Shindler has been known as a great teacher since he started teaching at UCI but I found his 162 class sort of difficult. His teaching style is sort of vague as he explains things in a subtlely condescending way, so it isn't easy to learn just through his lectures. His grading is fair with bi-weekly quizzes that take up a majority of your grade.

Material could be pretty difficult to understand so he assigns lots of homework to reinforce understanding. Hw includes reinforcement problems, problem sets, and practice quizzes. 3-4 quizzes in total with optional final. I think his teaching style is solid, you just have to put in extra work to do well.

Well... every time I have to go to youtube first then the textbook but still barely understand what happens in the lecture. He makes me feel like I'm an idiot because he skips too much stuff during the explanation. We have 4 * (reinforcements, problem sets, practice quizzes, quizzes) (16 in total) and a special final. He is approachable though.

Amazing professor that actually cares about his students and is passionate about algorithms. Lectures are energized and helpful. Homeworks give a good scope of the material and he releases practice tests that are formatted the same way. UCI is doing good job with bringing in new professors that are legends like Shindler.

Lectures were alright but he tended to go on distracting tangents (e.g., dragging on one of his stories for too long), and didn't prepare me for the HW very well; it was quite challenging. Fortunately he provided practice exams (and solutions to them) that rather accurately reflected what would be on the real ones. Textbook unnecessary. Ok overall
it was okay

He is one of the best professors I have ever had and without a doubt, I know that he will become a legendary ICS professor that is well-respected by many students. He is an excellent lecturer and gives rewarding homework and fair tests. I truly learned a lot about algorithms from taking his class.
He actually teaches. It's not an easy class, but it shouldn't be because algorithms are very important.

He's a cool guy and clearly knowledgeable about what he's teaching. 90% of the course grade is exam based. people either did really well or terribly on exams. VERY difficult to get partial credit. Lectures were informative but not really what's on the exam. Lecture slides were difficult to comprehend.
Great lectures, passionate professor. He explains concepts clearly and writes down notes on the slides during lecture so that we can get a better understanding of his thought process.

Really passionate professor who taught databases really well in lecture, homework can be kinda time consuming especially if you didn't attend lectures but otherwise were doable in the allotted time frame of a week. Midterms were fair and nothing you wouldn't expect, only gripe was for this quarter some of the TA's were straight horrible.

The class itself covers fairly simple content, but Professor Wong-Ma does a good job putting in the effort to engage the students. The midterms were difficult, but fair. She does a good job at making the workload light, but not trivial. Highly recommend to anyone looking tot take this course!

Amazing lectures although it's hard to follow along if you don't come to class. She posts her online videos a weekend before a test. Very responsive on EdStem. Homework is a 7.5 on the difficulty scale of 1-10. Canvas Quizzes are a 3. Despite her not posting videos to reinforce learning, I still believe she's a good professor.

The material is presented well in the lectures, but my main gripe is that these lectures aren't recorded and posted. There are notes, facets, and nuances that are said in lecture but not included on the slides, making it difficult to recall and refer back to if you missed it in your notes or in the lecture. She is responsive on EdDiscussion though.

Wong-Ma is super organized and passionate. She adapts the course to her students, making sure that the pace of her lectures follows everyone's overall understanding (i.e. she doesn't rush any of the material). 2 midterms, a final, & assignments+homework.
