Like her ICS 51 and 53, she makes sure that you learn rather than simply memorize the material.

Do not let angry students misguide your opinion of arguably one of the best professors in the school of ICS. If you care about your education and your goal is to gain applicable knowledge and skills surrounding a topic, then Wong-Ma is your go-to. Difficult and challenging, but fair and understanding. Show up, put in the effort, and you will excel.

This teacher definitely does not care about their students. She was constantly asked if she could upload the recorded lectures from previous quarters but she's so full of herself. She claims that it doesn't help students even though multiple students HAVE told her that it helps. Her slides are awful and don't contain all the information you need.

FInal is extremely hard. My grade jumps from A to F. 75 minutes for the final exam is not only for answering questions but also accepting the truth that I'm ineligible for college or too stupid to learn computer science.

While I loved 51 and 53 with Professor Wong Ma, 122A was less organized, so I didnt enjoy it as much. I wish her slides gave more examples of concepts, as you are required to use them in homework assignments. However, she does provide detailed video explanations after assignments are finished. She also has a very lenient late policy.

Jwong is approachable, enthusiastic and passionate about teaching. She gives tough exams, but you will definitely learn from her classes. Overall, she is a strong addition to the ICS department and a good professor

Professor Wong is a really good professor. She definitely does not deserve the amount of negative reviews that students are giving her. She is a passionate professor and THE BEST ics new hire. UCI students should appreciate her after getting the likes of Gassko and Wu. If you actually care about an education in CS take her. Put in work.

Professor Wong is a great lecturer and cares about her students. Her class isn't "easy", but that is because she is making you learn. This is exactly what classes should be like. They should be challenging and push you past your comfort zone. I learned a lot with Professor Wong, and she was always available if I needed help.

One of the few CS professors that TEACH in an engaging manner (especially in an upper div class), rather than just drone on through some PowerPoint slides. Made a class as dry as Databases somewhat interesting and educational.

Lectures are vague sometimes and the grader team is very stricted. Although she is super enthusiastic about the subject, she is not really good at explaining it. Knowing how to self study is a requirement for this class. Do evaluation for extra credit and the class got curved at the end.

At least the lecture slides and weekly quizz(not grading, only for attendence which are excellent free points) help you do the homework. Sample exams are good materials for review. She curves on final grades so if you only get an average score on exam and seems like a B- or C, don't feel sad, keep working and you might still get an A

UCI ICS hiring a highly competent, funny professor who can teach? Must be a mistake, we need more 'artists' like Wu and Alfaro! Jokes aside, Jwong is a pretty fantastic instructor, and managed to turn what I expected to be the most dry, useless filler class I'd be taking into something that I can (and have!) applied directly outside of school.

first time teaching here. ez hw. hard tests. Avg for tests were in the high 60s. Not the worst prof. I'm sure future classes will have an easier and more pleasant time now that the pioneers have been slaughtered, the terrain mapped, and the rough patches ironed out .

Nice person. Tries to engage otherwise disengaged students. Disconnect between hw and exams. Exams more related to lecture which unfortunately most people don't pay attention to. Mc questions obscure and most difficult. Reusing a previous professors test qs as prep sets different expectations than what was given, but better than nothing I guess
Jenny from the block is great! She's back. I failed the course, but I failed with honor.
She's amazing. Took this course even though I wasn't really interested in the subject but she made it fun and as interesting as a course in DB can be.

Shes an amazing professor, I was scared at first taking a new professor to UCI, but after a quarter with her, Im convinced that she is a great professor and she knows the material well and can teach it well. She engages with the students and she has a young and bubbly personality which relates to the students well. Homework is easy, tests fair.

lectures are clear and she's interactive/engaging, I think she's funny, made material understandable, homework was nothing too out of place/not insane & responsive on piazza, exams were fair, she's super helpful at office hours too, very easy to talk to and patiently explained questions/wants u to understand, one of the best CS profs I've had! (:

Berg's lectures were based on slides created by a different professor, primarily. Those slides, because they were written by someone else, obviously did not adhere to Berg's train of thought & presentation order... so he would frequently jump between slides & backtrack & just flip through them. & Exams were near-impossible to prep for.
Definitely a caring professor (he wants students to do well) but the class was not very organized, grades were released late, lectures were not that helpful. Generous curve at the end.

Honestly this class was the most disorganized class i ever took at UCI. The prof announced quizzes literally 2 days before. Half of the EdStem posts went unanswered (and some were answered after the final) and some were given conflicting answers. The midterm was rough, the final was okay, and final grades were posted late due to grading issues.

Hella disorganized. Quizzes not announced till like the week before so you can't plan flights or anything too far in advance, but there are only 4 quizzes w/ lowest 2 dropped (15% of grade). Jupyter hw (20%). Midterm (20%) + final(30%) w/ handwritten dbl-sided 8.5x11 notes. Project (15%) w/ slides interview w/ TA, then typed report

lectures felt like he was improvising on the spot as if he didnt create the slide, so theyre not helpful at all. youre on your own with the coding assignments. first midterm did not mirror the practice midterms, but the final was easier. One group project which he kept delaying until around week 9. felt pretty disengaged with the professor

My theory is that somebody needed to teach the class, and the only professor available was Berg who was busy with his own research and wasn't prepped to take over. Hopefully the organization of the class improves in future offerings; Berg shared lots of great anecdotes about his ML work in lecture and I felt like things got better towards the end.

i wanted to learn a lot from this class, but i learned as much as berg knows: not much. he stole all his material from previous professors and was still late in grading and releasing. he's a boring lecturer, and doesn't understand his slides (because he doesn't write them). his homework, exams, and project were not hard, at the very least.

Nothing was made by him, it was all stolen from Ihler. Had a midterm that was nothing like the practice and study material. The project was supposed to be released during week 6 but he decided to announce forming groups during week 10 so we had to cram in a 4 week long project in a couple days. Awful professor who doesn't care about anything. Avoid

Extremely lazy professor. All his slides copied from Ihler, reads them for the first time AS HE PRESENTS. Decided to do something original for once and created his own midterm which was NOTHING like ihler's midterms (some problems were never shown before) late final project half way week 9. final was chill because copy pasted previous questions

This class is all about self learning. Slides are copied from Professor Ihler's and genuinely feel ancient. Midterm was hard (it wasn't like the sample midterms at all) but final was mad easy with duplicate questions from past finals. Project got released late and had to cram it up. Class is an easy A if only he made the midterm easy like the final

If you want a professor that:
1. Goes 3 weeks without answering any questions on Ed Discussion
2. Releases final projects 1.5 weeks late (leaving you only 1 week)
3. Says material will not be covered on the final, and proceeds to do the opposite
4. Stops recording lectures without notice, and says he will upload them but never does
Choose Berg!

Completely steals all of Ihler's work. Extreme lack of communication between both the students and the TA's. No details on the project yet and it's week 10. Slides and diagrams are messed up because he's stealing it from Ihler. Inconsistent Canvas updating. Terrible professor. Just take it with Ihler, the professor who actually made the slides.

He is ok. He uses a lot of Ihler's slides. He covers a lot of advanced topics using complicated math that I haven't done in many years, so for me it feels overwhelming. He records the lectures though which is nice. Homework is through Jupyter Notebook and it's not anything insanely difficult but it's definitely time consuming
you know when you take his courses.

This class is very lecture heavy and kind of depends entirely on the lecture. Pay attention and you should be fine. He's a decent lecturer. Doing the homework is also important.
Tests are very straightforward and are almost identical to the practice tests. You don't need to expect a curveball on his exams.

Awesome lecturer, you will definitely learn in this class. Curves all exams, homeworks are lengthy but you will learn from them. Gives great exam prep before midterms and finals. Content of the class is tough, but if you go to lectures it makes it easier to learn.

Friendly professor who is clearly very knowledgable on the subject matter and is passionate about the field. Gives quite a few homework assignment but they are seriously helpful in helping learn the material, especially leading up to an exam. Slides have lots of content so sometimes hard to follow along, but highly recommend TAs and office hours.

The tests are easy if you have a basic grasp of the concepts. Lectures are super hard to understand, sudderth isn't a great lecturer. You're better off learning from StatQuest on youtube or MIT Lectures. Homework can get hard but the discussion code from the TAs is life saving. Everything is graded generally easily. Overall kind professor

Homework assignments are straight forward if you watch lecture and look for hints in the notes. Recommend getting a friend to compare answers with. Exams are easy if you study the lectures and do the past exams. Lectures overall are thorough and the professor is very responsive on piazza. Great class.

For probability, he is very good in my opinion. I think he provides great intuition on things, and his goal overall is understanding and not memorization. I love this about him and the way he structures his course. My only dislike of this course is that the homework can be unclear at times. Easier than other probability classes I've taken.

Granted everything moved online spring quarter and ML is just a really tough topic to begin with, I think Sudderth did okay at teaching it. He used videos from a diff professor as pre-lecture material and pretty much went over the same things in actual lecture. Tests were really tough because the concepts weren't really taught in detail.

nice dude, explains ML concepts rly well, 178 is just a hard class so stay on top of his homeworks, he gives access to practice tests that r pretty similar to the real tests, grades the group project pretty easy, pretty useful stuff to get your feet wet in ML

He is a really great lecturer. If you don't like probability, you probably won't enjoy this class. He does a good job at giving interesting and relevant examples for each topic during lecture. He gives weekly homework that will definitely require problem solving to finish, so start early. The exams were actually quite difficult, so study a lot!

Class is organized, homeworks are not very easy especially the coding part. Exams are also not very easy for the time given. Bad thing is he seems to be the only one teaching CS177 so you have to go through him. Good thing is he do curves on exams and give some mercy points even if you do totally wrong

Clear lectures and realizes that Math 2D isnt a prereq for the class so he doesn't focus to heavily on the math. The class material itself is fairly difficult. Homeworks are HARD but discussions are very useful. Exams are less difficult but still challenging. Use Ihler's lecture videos as supplementary material.

Professor Sudderth is great. He's super knowledgeable in the subject matter, and very clear in his speaking and communication of the material. I agree that sometimes I feel slightly dumb when asking questions in that class but he's always happy to help and be supportive. It's not an easy class but it ain't impossible either.

Professor Sudderth is very good at explaining math heavy concepts, favoring an intuitive explanation over showing a proof. Most of the difficulty of the course comes from the homework problems, which are like hard puzzles, they don't require much math to do, but figuring out how to solve the problem is the real skill being tested.

Nice guy but the class is way too difficult and crammed for a 10 week quarter. Next to no examples given in lecture which means you are going to be self learning for the homeworks. Doesn't inspire confidence when asking for help on the class forum and being told to read the lecture slides (again).

Considering he crammed a semesters worth of material into a quarter it makes sense that this class is tough. Definitely start the homeworks early and take advantage of office hours. Lectures cover more applications of the concepts in CS but homeworks deal with trivial problems using the formulas/math given but relatively unrelated concepts.
His 178 is only going to be worse, nice and helpful guy, but work load is way to crazy

While the professor is a very nice guy and clearly knows a lot, he makes the class extremely difficult and time consuming. The weekly homework can easily take up 10 hours to complete and the lectures are almost entirely theoretical, oftentimes with no worked examples. The only thing this class is good for is crushing your self-confidence.

Nice and knowledgeable. There is a lot of hw (weekly), but it's also 40% of grade. Each involves a bit of programming numpy/scipy (2 naive bayes classifiers so far). Worst part is the midterm. I have no clue how to study for it. Midterm is like looking at the hw for the first time, except no coding question. Praise the curve (80 as A- on midterm).

Professor is slow to return graded material. Homework problems are challenging. Tests are not similar to homework. Lectures lack examples, very theoretical. Wouldn't recommend taking courses with the Professor. He is very intelligent and passionate but seems to think he is still at Brown as the course is way too challenging.

Prof Sudderth is a very nice guy whom really knows his subject and care about his students. His lectures and materials are very well prepared and organized. Computer Science is HARD, especially the ML and stats part. If you pay attention in class, START HW EARLY and utilize office hours, you will do well. Or like the 1st cmt, go switch to Business
This course is the most difficult class I have ever taken in UCI. Do not take this if you have other options. HW is so hard and every question is like a small project.

Lectures were a little slow and would sometimes skip over content in the slides from time constraints, but quizzes/final was fair enough where it followed the format shown in discussions. Also posted years of previous tests to look at. Generous with extra credit with answering questions in lec + from performing well with your created AI.

5 in-person quizzes (30%), project (ours was MCTS checkers bot, 40% w/10% EC on proj grade), final (25%), course eval (5%). Ample practice materials. Cheatsheet allowed for quizzes/final. Pretty understanding, moved some quiz dates due to people's Thanksgiving schedules etc (no announcement tho). Total course grade curved up, but small near top end
Weekly quizzes and finals with two attempts online, but you keep the latest. Lectures can run dry b/c of his monotone voice. Learned quite the materials covered but learned quite a lot on projects.

171 as a class is interesting, it's just Professor Kask who kinda made it boring. Went online for half the quarter and the second half had weekly quizzes through Poll EV. Weekly quizzes which were all online and you get 2 attempts. Understand discussion slides and you are good. Final was also online with 2 attempts. Difficulty wise class is light.

didn't even show up to lecture until week 5, had a substitute teacher pop in a few times when he felt like it while he was still on vacation, we were notified a day in advance if not day of when the class was in person. keeps the LAST ATTEMPT on quizzes instead of best??? wants the worst for his students i guess. very disorganized too

Horrible and boring lecturer. Made first 6 weeks of class online. Online weekly quizzes takes recent score instead of best even though the entire class expressed their dislike for this. In-class quizzes were not organized well at all. Never wrote a rmp before but had to for him. Seems like he wants the worst for his students as he ignores feedback.

The first 6 WEEKS of lecture were online, and it was a toss-up whether or not he decided you should go in for a SUBSTITUTE teacher on certain select days. Online quizzes each week, two attempts LAST ATTEMPT TAKEN.  only take prof if you are okay with conflicting info, monotonous lectures, and weird grading

I would definitely say Kask is definitely the definition of an "okay" professor. He's not bad by any stretch of the imagination, but he's not greatest of all time. Lectures were rather slow and he unfortunately speaks rather monotonously, so it's up to you whether or not you think they're worth it. Weekly open note quizzes and open note final.

Lecture slides are terribly long (140 slides in a lecture topic) and professor scrambled to cover it all. Pretty easy two attempt weekly quizzes similar to questions from discussion. A lot of miscommunication occurred in the course between the TAs and the Prof, even before the strike, causing a good amount of confusion with the project and section.

Easy class, make sure you go to discussions to know how to do the weekly quizzes and what kind of questions will be on them. Lectures can be a bit complex, I recommend using the textbook as well as it has more examples. No homework apart from a single project that you have the entire quarter to do.

Fairly easy class. Grade is based on weekly quizzes, a group project, and participation polls, and the end of the quarter. The weekly discussions tell you how to solve the problems on the quiz and the project doesn't take that much time. I stopped watching the lectures after a time because they weren't helpful. Might be a hard class if TAs are bad.

Just watch the discussions to do well on the tests. Group project was pretty unorganized. My partner and I could not get our algo to work until we set up an office hours with kask. He stayed for hours until we got it to work. This man deserves a raise. He and TAs always willing to help. Just email them
Overall, it is a OK class. The class organization and communication are bad, but he gives deadline to make up for it.

He's very understanding of the COVID situation & gave a lot of extensions on deadlines for quizzes & project deadlines. He's a very nice & chill guy. His lectures are a little dull, but they are helpful for the quizzes. There were weekly quizzes (11 in total, lowest dropped), a group project, participation, & final. The final was optional.

This class is no longer easy. He made the projects way harder than previous quarters. Not responsive at all on Piazza so you can't even get your question answered. Basically you are left stranded on an island with no help.

There are some big problems. There is so much confusion. The professor contradicts with the TA. Section A contradicts with B. The lecture slides, textbooks, and discussions are contradict each other. Nobody knows what's really right anymore. They try to use new textbook and recycle old lecture vides, and they all disconnected. This is not good.

Kask has an erudite understanding of the subjects he teaches, and you will definitely have to learn if you want a good grade in his class. At the same time, he has also been one of the most fair and understanding professors I've had. UCI is very lucky to have Professor Kask.

He changed policies when he realized they werent working. His explanations in lecture were crystal clear though he himself is a bit monotone. His project was cool and grading criteria was pretty easy. Weekly quizzes but they arent hard. He gives you all past quizzes/exams for you to study so you have everything you need to succeed in this class :)

He's very responsive on Piazza. He makes participation on piazza necessary but the points are actually very easy to get imo. He was very lenient throughout the quarter, making exams optional, dropping quizzes, making more fair policies. The transition to online was good I think, and he was very open to criticism and change
I think you should avoid
Makes piazza posts mandatory. They have to be endorsed too. Not good. Not fun. Leads to low effort piazza spam posts.
The class was very unstructured, and there were people constantly complaining on Piazza. Also his lectures were SOOOO dry.

This class was test/quiz heavy; there were 5 quizzes, 2 midterms and a final. Exam material only covered material from lecture slides (which are posted online), though some questions covered small details that were hard to remember. Lectures were monotone in my opinion. Only discussion attendance was mandatory.

One of my most favorite classes. Covers a lot of important topics that have many practical applications. The professor is super knowledgeable and cares about his students. Generous curve but test/quiz heavy. Took this during Summer Session 2.

He is a great Computer Science professor. Material was straight forward, and tests were fair. On his tests/quizzes he'll have a lot of True/False questions, so make sure you know all the bold and bullet points on the lecture slides. Lectures can be a bit dull, but the slides make up for lecture. He also had a generous overall curve for the class.
Great lecturer. Incredibly well spoken and intelligent. Yet casual and can explain things simply.

Great lecturer. I enjoyed this class with Smyth. 5 assignments (1 dropped), midterm, final, and final project. Lectures recorded, but I enjoyed them in person. The notes provided are great. No curve. Very fair and I learned a lot. Interesting course, I highly recommend.

Very good lecturer. If you put in the work, you will do well in the class and learn a lot. No surprises on tests, it is everything that is covered in lecture and homework. Decent amount of homework, but TA's are very helpful and have many office hours. 5 homework, 1 group project, and midterm and final.
Great teacher and amazing lecturer. Explains ML concepts very thoroughly in an easy to understand way, readily available on ed discussion, and overall nice and funny guy. TAs are also very nice.

This was a project course so the majority of our grade depended on reports and stuff like that. Overall, class was pretty easy. His class focuses on natural language processing. I think if I were more interested in the material i would think he was an amazing professor. He managed to get me interested in material on occasion so i think he's alright

Never seems to reply to posts on Ed. The cache server we need for the web scra​per project was constantly going down. However, this class is SUPER easy. 4 quizzes, lowest dropped (25%), final (25%). Exams are hella free. 3 projects (50%. last 2 r group proj and take some effort and have zoom interviews w/TAs who ask about ur implementation).
Good luck getting this prof to respond to anything. Fun class tho

Cache server always down. ~1600 lecture slides. Final exam was nothing like what she said we would be tested on (lectures instead of the prev. 5 quizzes). TAs/Prof messed up the final exam grade and my final interview grade, but later fixed. Very unprofessional. Search engine offered extra credit (+5% grade). GET GOOD GROUP MEMBERS! Fun projects

I liked Information Retrieval, both material and projects. Professor is passionate and her lectures are helpful, but aren't mandatory to pass the class. Projects are difficult due to vague requirements and bad test server for the web crawler, but the code interviews are easy to pass. I did A1 alone and it was hard, get a group for sure

A3 search engine is not meant for intermediate python programmers, you have to hope you have a Python expert in your team. CS and SWE majors forced to do a harder version with more web pages. Prof should teach some advanced python code that would be useful for A3. Course prereqs were C and Java courses, but no Python… misleading. (3/4)

Nor any elaboration on exception handling. Instructions are poorly defined. Maybe don't be vague and do your real job as a TA, push students in the right direction and define requirements better. Web crawler did not go smoothly, server would constantly be down for many days and only 12-24 hours worth of extensions were given for testing. (2/4)

Spring 2025: TAs would constantly be vague regarding clarification on some poorly worded quiz 1 questions on tokens and would give conflicting information, resulting in students losing points unfairly for following instructions. TAs would intentionally be vague on A1, with no set criteria/rubric on what test files to expect (1/4)

She's ok. They are slow on grading projects and sometimes the quizzes can be bullshit. But overall this class isn't that difficult as long as you dont procrastinate. One annoying thing though is that the cache server used for the web crawler project always crashes and its hard to have your program finish before the server shuts down.

A project-based class with vague instructions, criteria, and deadlines. The questions on quizzes are sometimes confusing and are often questions where you know it or you don't. Students are not allowed to ask questions to clarify in quizzes. Class content is interesting but lectures are often uninteresting.
Unorganized courses and quizzes are either you know it or not. Materials are not based on overall concepts but instead on comments that are mentioned once and are not in the lecture slides.
One of the most unclear classes at I have ever taken. She does not even know what her own class is about. Extremely chaotic assignments where no one knows the due date.
The course design is confusing and chaotic.
The most awful CS course I have taken so far at UCI... Everything is underspecified, even the grading scheme for the quizzes are inconsistent. Avoid taking this course from her.

You'll create a web crawler and web scraper. Lopes wasn't a great lecturer, wasn't super engaging. Concepts require an intermediate level of understanding. Quizzes aren't too difficult and are open notes. Start on projects early because it gives you more time to debug your web scraper that may take 2 hours or more just to finish.

I feel that the professor's slides are sometimes too complicated to understand. Also TAs don't have clear grading criterias. My team was not given a itemized rubric, only the final grade on both major projects. Pretty avg class, not amazing but not the worst either. To future students: make sure your teammates don't suck

Personally, I did not think highly of this professor. She's consistently rude, vague, and overall teaches very little and expects much of her students. Trying to get ahold of her was like trying to find a missing semicolon in 5000 lines of code. Make sure to keep up with the discussions as they're necessary to pass the quizzes and do the projects.

She deserves a much better rating. Assignments weren't that crazy conceptually but still took a while. She doesn't hold your hand as much as other professors during assignments but she is still extremely helpful if needed. The quizzes and final were pretty easy. Discussions helped a lot for exams. Overall very chill (and interesting) class.

Been a while since someone reviewed her but she's changed a lot I think. Homework is now much clearer and though not polished, you can always ask her to clarify on Piazza. Quiz questions can have some weird wording but you can negotiate with her afterwards. Some may say dry but I think her lectures are packed with useful info.

Homework was among the vaguest I've ever had. She rarely responds to questions online, so you just have to ask her in person or the TAs for help. She is a pleasant person, but her lectures are nothing special. Quizzes do not correlate with lecture notes very well. Would not take again.

75% homework, 5% quizzes, 20% exams (midterm + final).
Most people got around 100% on homeworks and quizzes (which are async), so while there is no curve on the exams (which likely had an average in the 60's-70's), the distribution was definitely focused around A's and B's. 
Start early on the homeworks and read the study guide. Content is cool.

Mostly project-based (75% of grade): 6 Jupyter notebooks which aren't too hard. Online Canvas quizzes (5%), in-person midterm and final (10% each, 8.5x11 notes allowed). No real exam prep materials/questions, just vague list of topics. Don't expect practice exams. Midterm avg was 62.5%, final exam grade not released. NO CURVE. Zotistics is outdated

pretty standard class, thought the midterm review guide didn't really reflect the actual midterm, but most of the weight is on the assignments anyways which are fair and pretty rewarding to do (the last two were the most fun). professor is clearly knowledgeable although the material comes off dry during lecture

Graded on five projects where you fill out some Jupyter notebooks. Topics are pretty interesting and the professor's lectures are engaging. You basically get to do implement all of the interesting parts of these algorithms without having to suffer through hours of boiler plate code. Class is overall interesting and fairly easy.

He is very accessible outside of class and is really the best caring. This class involves a ton of linear algebra. Our final was 3D reconstruction given many images of an object. We work on it throughout the quarter. Oddly, this course was a bit easier than his CS116 class. Really cool class. I hope he can teach more courses besides 116/117

The material is pretty challenging. The most I've used calculus/linear-algebra outside of math class. His lectures and the material is incredibly interesting and refreshing. Some machine learning involved in course but very little. Start homework early and make sure you understand lectures before doing hw or you will have an awful time. Great guy,

The projects are in Python now and are challenging. The professor himself is pretty average with fine lectures. My major complaint is that the project instructions and the advice given on Piazza are at odds. Trying to decipher the project instructions and comparing them to advice on Piazza can be misleading at times. Vague requirements.

Amazing professor. Actually helps students. Projects are mostly fun but can be a pain to debug. For this year the projects were in python, I'd prefer MATLAB but it works fine. Projects can be a pain to debug. Final are open notes.

He's very knowledgeable in Computer Vision, his lectures are decent (enthusiastic). Grade is determined by 5 projects and a final. The projects are pretty challenging but definitely have you apply the material covered by the lectures, reinforcing your learning.
Professors know his material very well. Must Read a lot. Skipping classes not advised.

Nice prof, could get by without going to lec just study before mt/final. Overall average course that didn't take up more time than it needed to. I will say that the TAs weren't too helpful and final group project, while not bad was very disorganized.

The course material is pretty dry and heavy so the lectures are not the most interesting. However, the grading policy is fair and if you study, the midterms are not hard at all. Just be sure to read HW instructions very closely and ask TA's for clarification. Overall not a bad class at all just a bit boring unless you really love databases.

Teacher has the most unentertaining lectures. But they are important to listen to. I feel like some topics should've been easier but the concepts were either poorly explained or I just could not focus during lecture even though I went to all of them (Attendance not required). Overall easy class. Final project is simple. Don't do homeworks last min.
the goat of 122a

One of the nicest professor ever and truly cares about students. Class was not easy but A is very doable. 4 HWs, 1 group project, 1 midterm and 1 final. He takes students input very seriously and tried his best to improve his lecture. Always appreciates questions.

Definitely not an easy class like I thought it would be, gets tougher after the halfway point. But you really get to learn a lot about working with databases and database design which is a great skill to have in the work industry
Learned lots in this class, some concepts took a lot of practicing to understand. Nawab's a chill guy who has a lot of knowledge about what he is teaching.

A great professor who clearly wants you to succeed. Asks for input about improving his lectures (which are great). Course material is not something you can easily get by without lectures and discussion or help from friends. Very understanding and responsive to questions and concerns. Lectures were recorded but examples are best seen in person.

Very kind professor. Cares about his students and really passionate about what he is teaching, and is very knowledgeable in the subject; he takes time to answer all questions he can. Homework is rather tough, but there is a generous 24hr late policy if you need it. Other assignments (worksheets and quizzes) are rather easy and fast to complete.

Very dense lectures, but professor tries his best to simplify concepts. Overall an easy class to get a good grade even if you don't understand all facets of the lectures: homeworks make you work with libraries, exams reflect pretty closely to previous years, and project is exploratory.

Great lecturer, sometimes too smart for his own good. He's passionate and knowledgeable but at times he goes on mini tangents/ walks through math in a way you'd only understand with some exposure to the material beforehand. He records all his lectures which is super nice and is insanely lenient with the curve for midterm and final. Nice guy overall

Professor Ihler is definitely a great choice for machine learning. Although, in fact, he could make his lectures a bit easier, I felt like he covers every topic in detail, even the easiest ones like clustering with k-means. His assignments are not bad, just require time. Redo past exams for midterm/finals and you will do well.

I genuinely tried listening to his lectures and gave up. I even wrote notes to try to pay attention and it just didn't help with understanding the material. The final was much more difficult than the midterm. The project was okay, but make sure you have good teammates you can rely on.

Great overview class. Mateiral was tough but he explained it well. Pretty hilarious at times and I thought the lectures were entertaining. You definitely need to study for this class and do the homework to get anything out of it. And he's pretty hot for a prof.

Lectures are math-heavy, but the homework is not on the math at all. A midterm and a final which had to be curved because he asked the most obscure details that were neither the math of the lecture nor the enforced material of the homework. A final group project too, but wasn't graded too harshly. Forgets to publish homework and unresponsive online

There were recorded lectures. I feel like the homework was decently difficult but didn't prepare me for the test all that well. The midterm was very difficult and honestly a couple questions weren't related to the content we learned nor past exams. The final was fair as we learned it all. 5 HW and 1 group project.

Do you want spend your weekends doing homework? Are you interested in taking exams your professor doesn't prepare you for? Do you love it when your professor delays the group project for weeks so that you can cram it all right before finals? Isn't it also the best when they submit final grades incorrectly? If you like those things, then take Ihler

He's a nice guy and likes what he does. Homeworks are very practical and doable, but lectures and exams are horrible. He's late, both with making it to lecture and posting assignments. Lectures help you with nothing so you learn it all yourself. Midterm and final grades are D averages, so save yourself stress and depression and take another guy.
Irresponsible Prof. t say the least released the project really late and his exams are ridiculously hard. Just now the avgs for exams were nearly below 50%. It may even be lower now.

Terrible lecturer, smart but does not know how to teach. Has test questions that are not taught in class, you're expected to learn how to solve them yourself. Homework questions are nothing like test questions, assigned project on week 8 when he was supposed to post it week 4. Always late to class for some reason.

Lectures were extremely conceptual, but homework was much easier. No tests, just weekly(ish) homeworks, participation quizzes, and a final project. Start homeworks early and you should be fine. Professor seemed very friendly and willing to help you.

He's a genius in the field of ML and graphical models no doubt. The problem is simplifying that to something understandable to undergrads. His lectures are master degree level content and he even joked about it once. We would be lost on the hw if it wasn't for the guide rails he provides. I've barely understood anything in this class.

This class was very disorganized, and it was self-evident from the conflicting information the professor and TAs provided. There were typos in the slides and assignments at times, some which he claimed he would fix but never did. Professor Ihler seems like another professor that cares more about his research than the education of his students.

The class itself is pretty difficult, which has led me to going to Professor Ihler's office hours to seek out help. I noticed at times he would be looking down at his phone when I was asking my question, where he would ask me to repeat myself several times. Doesn't feel like he really cares, especially when the lecture posts are constantly delayed.

This class was really interesting and the concepts were pretty hard. The professor does a really good job explaining the concepts and is very helpful with HW. Grading breakdown: 65% HW, 25% Final Proj, 10% participation/quizzes. The quizzes are really easy/simple and are just there to make sure you're caught up with the material. HW can be hard.

He has to be one of my favorite professors. Super funny, understanding, and not too hard. Most of the learning comes from homework. Take them seriously and you'll get A. He gives you everything for you to succeed, you just need to do your part. He explains complex things so easily, anyone could understand. The course isn't as math-heavy as id like.

179 is the hardest class conceptually that I've taken (out of 178, 171, 122A, 161), Ihler explains well & I think I understand everything till I get to the hw & I'm lost, everything went over my head, Ihler grades easy on group project & answers piazza/personal questions well, all my hws  blindly using starter code & massaging it into new answers

Ihler is a super amiable, humble, and knowledgeable professor. Extremely helpful during lectures and piazza. Class structure is 5 HW's, lowest one dropped, and one project. No midterm or final. HW's are difficult but can be done through Piazza help and asking for help. Content is extremely math heavy, but Ihler adjusts hw to make it easier for us.

Ihler is a really smart guy, but he's not a really good teacher. There are 5 homeworks (1 gets dropped), a project, a midterm, and a final. He gives you past tests for you to look at which are very similar to the tests he gives you. So if you know how to do the past tests, you should get a good grade.

Class is fine. Guy is super flexible (got rid of 1 hw), I literally said to him on piazza "This is too hard to write can I use the wikipedia algo" and he said sure . lmao. I wish he had videos for this class like his 178 tho. Also as people say hw can be vague sometimes, but I still do it 1-2 days before and am fine and I'm not that smart.

Ihler is a fairly eloquent and thorough lecturer. However, the fact that his HW assignments are so vague and that his TA's are completely unresponsive to students' HW questions really made this class much harder than it had to be. Topics are very conceptual and hard to grasp-- ended up learning more from Google than I did from his slides.

I really want to like Professor Ihler but I just can't seem to grasp anything that is going on in class. The material is impossibly complex, and the pace of the class is faster than I can keep up. Only lectures will dissect the material, but the HW examples do not transfer well to the homework at all. It almost feels like a graduate level course :/

Overall, the class doesn't seem organized. TA's almost never respond to the questions on Piazza, so important questions are almost always left unanswered. Lectures were extremely dense-- heavy theoretical concepts and math formulas. TA's are extremely slow at grading (HW1 finally got graded by week 5). Grading scheme is 70% HWs, 30% group project.

Nice guy and he's super smart. This leads to lectures being pretty dense and intimidating, but thankfully assignments and exams aren't as complicated as lecture. Learned a decent bit about ML. Very fair class.

The lecture is very detailed and it can be overwhelming, especially for those that aren't particularly well-versed in statistics/ calculus. Despite the intimidating lectures, the grading is fairly lenient and if you put in the work you'll do well. I recommend learning the topics from Udacity when you can. His lectures can be hard to follow.

Hard material/class. I was scared for the course at first because I had no idea what he was even saying, but things got better as the course went on. Fat curve on the midterm. Our final was much easier than expected. HW is annoying but doable. I wouldn't want to take it with anyone but Ihler!

Lecture material is dense and extremely difficult. He is definitely smart, but I feel like he's on a different wavelength from his students. If you understand him, fine, but I just couldn't understand a thing. Homework is annoying since you use numpy and the material can be hard. However, tests are fair and allow cheat sheets.

He is NOT interested in teaching, the lectures are very dense and difficult to understand, and responds to ONLY 20% of Piazza posts ON THE DAY BEFORE HW is due. Doesn't care about his students. Always runs a few minutes late to class everyday and can get a bit snarky and impatient. Only take the course if you're TRULY interested in the subject...

Professor Ihler is smart... almost too smart for his students. Exams are difficult but fair, and homework assignments cover the material relatively well. He is usually very quick to respond to any questions, which is a godsend considering how dense the material can be. This is not an easy course, but a good look into the future of machine learning.

Professor is extremely patient and willing to teach everybody. He has a lot of experience in the subject and has online videos to supplement the course. Course was great and a lot of fun, but quite a bit of work.
Really great professor who loves to help students. The material of the class can be tough but he's always willing to give extra help in office hours and the homework/tests are reasonable.

it is flipped lecture style: at home you watch about 5 videos posted the day before each lecture and during lecture you practice problems as a class. Though, sometimes the videos are posted late. He mandates attendance via PollEverywhere and you have to use Lockdown browser for the quizzes.

chill professor who lectures well on the content and the details in the projects. Projects are in groups of 2. There was a total of 5 projects with the last one being a creative one. The homework assignments were zybooks graded on participation activities. pretty straightfoward class if you're good with hardware

Well-organized course with a lot of freedom for projects. Prof Gago explains complex ideas clearly and checks in often to keep us on track. Fair grading and quick feedback, and he is very approachable. You will work hard but feel supported the whole way.

Cool professor, interesting topics, hands on labs. Weekly quizzes on the lectures aren't too difficult. The labs can be a little vague with the instructions but are doable. Lots of freedom for the final project (which is the final). The professor is understanding and flexible.
Chill and easy class. No exam, No stress. 90% of the grade are group project and lab. Quizes are easy and straight forward. Go to lab hour, TA are super helpful.

Professor Gago really made lectures fun and you can tell he loves what he teaches. He was super helpful even after class, always ready to lend a hand and was cool about changes and stuff, and definitely one of the smartest teachers I've had so far. I totally recommend taking his class.

Kind professor that cares about his students. The lectures are a bit divisive on whether or not they're good. I personally think he's a good lecturer and also throws in a couple good jokes; I feel like the monotony comes from SOME portions of the subject itself (not all). He also is responsive to students' needs; extending assignment due dates.

Excellent teacher. Genuinely no complaints since he was super enthusiastic about the course. You'll work with mobile frameworks but the TA's aren't really knowledgeable in certain frameworks. There was 3 quizzes that you take online. No final exam but you have a final project to complete. The TA's seem very relaxed with the grading of the project.

Gago's CS125 was both informative and enjoyable. The assignments and quizzes were fair and really helped me understand the concepts. The final project was an awesome chance to practice what I'd learned, and I liked that I could pick my own topic. I really recommend this class with Gago.

I found the lectures super interesting and informative. The course itself wasn't too hard, but I learned a lot about recommendation systems. The quizzes were fine, nothing too crazy. And the best part was the course project - it wasn't too restrictive, so you could really let your creativity flow.
Easiest cs class I've ever taken

CS 125: build a full stack mobile app. Listed prereqs are too shallow -- at least one group member needs to know some sort of mobile dev, and backend could require extensive programming knowledge. Project outcome depends on the group you form in Week 1. Bad group => rushed project. Lots of creative freedom for the project though.
If taken online it was the best class, but had him before in an in person class, and my expectations dropped!Assignments are very heavy and need to start really early to be able to finish on time!

Great guy, he took my midterm evaluation seriously and did make change to his class. Not every professor cares about negative reviews. The course was easy cuz he lowered project requirement. I honestly wish to learn more but he isn't very familiar with the material. Still, he is a great, honest, humble teacher, I like him a lot.

Lecture material was pretty simple and the quizzes were straightforward from the lecture slides. Project was based on making a health web/mobile app and grading was super lenient by the TAs. Course feels like it might be a toned down, simpler version of the senior design capstone project course that Gago offers.
Very caring and flexible professor. 5 labs and a final project which weren't hard. There were biweekly quizzes based on the lecture. No midterm nor final.

Sergio was good at explaining the real-world applications of IoT, and the labs and assignments provided helped me to understand the material. So far, this has been the most enjoyable course at UCI I've ever taken. There is room for improvement anyways, and professor said he will improve, as this was his first time teaching it.

Projects were the hardest part of the class because of how vague it was and it took forever to actually test the code, but the quizzes were pretty easy and were very similar to the previous year's quizzes that he made available on canvas. Pretty easy grader on most projects.

Professor Gago really cares about his students. He makes difficult concepts easy to understand and he is always willing to help students or even change things to accommodate special cases. I like how his lectures are recorded so students can focus on either writing notes or listen in lecture and go back to the recording in case they miss something.

Overall he is an amazing professor who really cares about the students. The lectures and quizzes are easy, but his assignments are challenging. As long as you attend the initial q&a discussions for each assignment then it is clear what to do. You can work by yourself or in groups of 3. If you time manage well then it is pretty doable alone.

He's a really nice dude and he really cares about his students and the feedback he receives. The lectures and quizzes are fairly easy, but the coding assignments are pretty challenging compared to what goes on in lecture. You're able to work with a group of up to 3 people though.

Prof. Gago is my favorite professor I've had so far at my 3 years at UCI! He's funny, cares a lot about the students, & is such a genuinely passionate teacher. It was refreshing. Material isn't hard & I learned a lot about how search engines work, it was very interesting. There are group projects, which are fine as long as you put in some time!

This man was such a good professor I made an account just to say how awesome he is. He is charismatic, funny, and very knowledgeable. Although his classes are recorded and posted online (which is a good thing if you have to miss), I would highly recommend going to his lectures. He really cares about his students and the assignments are not too bad.
Sergio is an awesome teacher! Most of his class was based off the lecture slides.

Great Professor, very passionate about topic and is kind, caring, and understanding. Put in effort and you'll get an A. No midterms, only hw + discussion, in which both aren't too bad. There is a final project, but it's not too bad as well. Class overall very chill.
A truly amazing amazing teacher. The passion she showed for bioinformatics is inspirational and kept me motivated throughout the quarter.

Jing is an amazing teacher, especially when you consider how much information she is providing and how new the field of bioinformatics is. There are a few homeworks you have the last 4 weeks to do you final project which you can have a partner for. Getting an A is easy but the class has tons of potential for learning. Definitely recommend.

Entire class graded on 2 midterms and a non cumulative final (all 33.3%). Topics after the second midterm become extremely more confusing. However, completely blindsided the class with a final that was NOTHING like the practice final….also asking questions we were not given practice on, so beware of the final.

He has good slides and brings good vibes to classes. There is no homework so the grade is just from the exams. He makes reasonable exams and provides previous examples for what to expect. His slides are also pretty good, but I find that the topics are too complicated to be explained well on its own so I also use Youtube. Overall, he is good though.

35% midterm and 45% final, only graded on a few specific questions. 20% homework assignments. Very difficult class. Curve at end. Prof is okay lecturer. Decent notes but no recordings of lectures which would've been helpful.

The course (midterm + final) covers A LOT of content. Questions on those tests feels like you either know it or you don't. The course isn't easy, but lectures are concise & detailed. Professor is very inclusive: he co-writes Wikipedia articles (instead of using a textbook) and considers accessibility (e.g. color-blindness) in his lecture slides.
Very routine professor with no surprises. Homework was graded mainly based on effort but midterm and final were worth 90% of the grade but he gives a generous curve on the final grade of the class.

Exam problems are very challenging and going to lecture seems worthless. One can read his notes and get a high grade as well. Each exam problem worths 20 points for the midterm and 12 points for the final. If you miss something or accidentally did something wrong, you will get so many points off and one letter grade down. NOT FAIR

Didn't upload any notes so we have to take notes every lecture. Gave easy midterms so we expected easy final exam, but the final was very hard. It put too much weight on analysis but didn't care how algorithm works. Never get back our final grade so we will never know what was going on in our finals.

He powers through the lectures, writing faster than you can keep up with. Doesn't explain the algorithms, just barfs them onto the paper. You will need to spend a considerable amount of time on your own to keep up in this class. Learned an absolute ton, but it was a lot of self study rather than guidance. Good luck!

He is very respected and good at answering questions. His MT and Final are very fair and the curve is pretty generous. The only con is having to hand copy notes as he writes them in class, hand starts to hurt after awhile.
Excellent lecturer, very knowledgeable. Not helpful to students. No literature, just a bunch of (mostly) wikipedia links. HW is good but only 20%.

You'll have to attend every lecture, he doesn't post up any notes online. He also writes all of his notes down so you have to copy it. The homeworks are easy if you have perfect lecture notes (they reference the subjects in the notes). The midterm had simple but specific questions (in a wide range of topics). Thank god they gave partial credit.
Has become progressively more hirschberg with only theroetical examples as quarter has gone on. You gonna write so much you gonna be on that carpal tunnel time for sure cuz he don't post lectures.
I took CS161 in fall and professor Eppstein is absolutely knowledgeable. He always answers questions patiently and you will learn a lot from his lecture.

He's a great professor, his notes are clear and his lectures are clear.  His exams are really hard though.  Homework is fine, but don't compare to his exams.  There's lots of note taking, I used my entire notebook for his class. He doesn't post his notes up, so you'll have to attend every lecture.  Discussion is really helpful too.

One of the best lecturers I have had on campus. He does not post notes online and hand writes notes in class so attendance is mandatory to pass, especially since he deviates from the book. Weekly homework to  reinforce topics. Lectures were interesting. Exams tested your understanding of the topics, not memorization. Highly recommended!!!
lectures very dense, courseload light, not too difficult, but you do have to put in effort

Solid professor. He is anything you can ask for in a professor, nothing more nothing less. Do your homework, go to discussion to learn a few things, study up and you'll do fine. Very fair exams. Lectures are fine.
very time consuming class but will learn a lot. one of the hardest class i took at uci
Difficult material. Make sure to do all the readings before lecture. Lectures are vague and speeds through a lot of topics. Other 161 professor has similar homework but slightly more difficult exams.

This guy just gets straight to the point. He teaches everything really clearly and reasons through everything. The why and how are always clear. I never tried office hours or went to discussion so I don't know how responsive he is, but I think he is a good professor.

Dry lectures aside (thank goodness they are only 50 minutes), Professor Eppstein is perhaps one of the most knowledgeable professors at UCI. His lecture notes are very useful with the help of visual aids and examples. His exams can be a bit tough as they focus on deep understanding of the material, but the class itself is not too difficult.

Definitely have to read up and know the material. David is interesting and knowledgeable. I don't believe it is hard to receive an A for CS161, just know your stuff. Class work load is very low. Fun and good class to take. Supposedly the other 161 prof is a hard grader, so take it with David!

Others are right about his lectures being vague, he is the only person who understand what he is saying. Not only that, his exams are vague too. The material is hard, and I would read stuff online or from book, but exams are really similar to his lectures. I did not like the class overall, but he's fine!

One of the smartest professors out there, although he is very dry. Exams are based exclusively on lectures, which often differs from the book, so be sure to attend. He is responsive and a generous grader, but his notes are very fast paced and sometimes sloppy, so you must pay attention. Material itself is fair enough.

Lots of dense material, so lectures will sometimes be boring. However, if you take good notespictures or have good memory, you'll do fine-- anything he talks about in lecture can show up  on exams, so don't be fooled by sample exams or stress over HW as exams are all really lecture-specific. He's a very generous grader and helps when asked.

Professor Eppstein taught us a lot of useful and interesting algorithms. Although he went through his materials too fast, you will be able it catch it up if pay full attention. He answered my email in a way that inspires me to figure out the answer. Prepare to know all O-Notations he mentions in class and you will do fine. He is a generous grader.

Brilliant professor, algorithms course can be challenging. The material is fair enough but you HAVE to go to lecture and pay attention. Learning the algorithms out of the book won't be good enough because he has all sorts of variations and add-ons in his lectures that he will test on. Class isn't hard if you pay attention in lecture, tricky if not.

Eppstein writes down everything you need to know on the black/white board, from MEMORY. He definitely knows his stuff, and he actually looks at the students when lecturing, so that he can answer their questions. 20 percent of the test questions seem to be trivially easy, the rest are about the right difficulty.

when i took the class the two midterms and finals were whack. i totally bombed them. they were based mostly off his lectures. his test making skills suck. he offers previous exams, but do not be deceived by them. his tests are completely different except one or two problems.
Doesn't explain things well, and his exams are difficult to answer well.
Hate this class !!!!

Amazing professor and super engaging content if you're trying to learn real-world webdev tools. Probably the most practical class I've ever taken. The projects demand an insane amount of work time, mostly with debugging, but as long as you have the time to spare it's not too hard of a course to do well in.

Very chill and nice professor who also gives tips about the industry. The projects are VERY HARD and will demand a lot of your time, but you will learn so much in this class. If you are interested in web development or anything database related, this class is a must take. Exposure to a lot of technologies and big data management.

Herold really challenges you to learn topics quickly and apply them, but the pay off is worth it for how much you learn in this class. You leave the class with a finished product you can be proud of and industry knowledge.

Definitely one of the more engaging profs here at UCI, also really like his section of practical CS/career tips at the end of lecture. Tough late policy, but he is understanding if you communicate a valid reason to him 🙏🏻 Would recommend if you want to learn a lot of useful material, quickly, but you def have to put the time/effort in!!

Great, fun professor. Since this class is completely focusing on one project, lectures are often cut short because he doesn't need to lecture on a ton of content, he more-so just guides you along for the project. He does code reviews sent in by students and talks about things in the CS industry. Healthy EC opportunities with the project as well.

Great professor! Amazing lectures, and it helps that he teaches very small classes (~30 students). Your grade is entirely based on 2 exams and 2 projects, very few things, but that also means this class has a very low workload. Just pay attention to his lectures and you'll be fine.

Wayne Hayes was a great professor that I enjoyed quite a lot. He's compassionate and really appreciates how difficult it is for students to fully memorize the subject material in a class like CS146. As a result our lectures and exams were made as straightforward as possible and of course, at the end, there is a big curve! Thanks Professor Hayes.

Do not know about 6b but his 146 is not bad. I honestly learned a lot. Easy midterm, Hard Final. He curves generously. His exams are generally outside the homework materials. Due to so many complaints from spring 2017, his class was organized this time. He has weird grading criteria for finals but should not hurt that much.

Course teaches you a lot of practical linux skills such as how to automate tasks with bash scripts. Material is not too difficult, its a rehash of ics53 and cs143a. Hayes is really engaging lecturer.  Great elective, every CS major should take. Disorganization in spring2017 was due to a grader that waited until week10 to grade HWs...

He doesn't care about his students or his student's grades. Nothing was delivered back to the students on time. You would think that because they used scripts to grade our homework(which still had errors in them anyway) that we would get them back faster, but nope. Avoid this professor at all costs if you care about your grade
Poorly organized, one of the worst class I have ever taken.

I honestly really enjoyed this class. The material was easy to understand, and not extremely convoluted. One of the biggest things you should do is go to class; although attendance isn't mandatory, it's definitely beneficial and will help you to pass the class. Don't listen to everyone complaining about the class. Would definitely recommend.

any1 from spr 17 will rant about this class. We have 5 proj,divided in 10 weeks. by  day of final(wk11), we had grades for first 2 proj, and that's it. no mt grade, so no chance to look at it. pract mt had nothing to do with mt. we thought that was bad, but he then he test diff student on diff materials,so the final was unfair. worst. class. ever.

Very helpful on a personal basis, good mentoring, though since this was an individual research course, I cannot speak regarding his lecturing skills in larger classes. Regardless, the hands-on projects and independent study allowed for flexible learning and contributing to actual computer science research.

He loves Unix, & thus the material too. Some hw's are challenging. Tough grader, but adjusts grades in the end. Broad on test topics (can be anything). READ THE LECTURE NOTES (every word), pay attention in class, & do the homework (totals to 50% of the grade), and you'll be fine. I learned a ton & really enjoyed the material/his sense of humor.

Professor Hayes is great. His class is very interesting and he really does his best to prepare you for work in "the real world". Even though it's only an elective, I recommend CS 146 as a great class.

Wayne Hayes is a good professor even though he can be disorganized sometimes. It was the only class in Spring quarter where I didn't fell asleep. However, be prepared to work HARD in order to at least pass the class. His midterm and his final was quite DIFFICULT even though he curves the exams and the overall grade.

Very straight forward class -- it's UNIX, so go-to resources are abundant.  Prof does a good job teaching the innards of UNIX and hw assignments are self-explanatory.  Downfall is that the grade is broken down into a small number of assignments/exams (as are virtually all upper divs).  Grading criteria / scaling is generous. Best to know C pgrm'ing

Professor Hayes is very passionate about the Unix operating system and therefore provides very detailed and in depth lectures. I would highly recommend taking this class if you want to learn more about Linux and C, but not if you care about your grades (though grades are highly dependent on the TA which sucks). Assignments are long but worth it.
If you ever feel lost after taking ICS 51/53 series but still want to learn unix / C programming, take CS 146 with this professor.

Professor had lots of experience and knowledge on the subject.  Course projects were very challenging and time consuming (for those with no experience with Unix and C).  Lectures could get slightly boring at times.  Course was very tough however I learned a lot and would recommend this professor, but be ready for a challenge.
I enjoyed Professor Hayes CS146 course. Not sure about previous comments, but when it comes to something he's enthusiastic about he certainly puts in an extra effort.
Explains things fairly well. Exams are on the easy side. Homework is light. Solid professor for 161.

Honestly, his course is not that bad but the lectures are kinda boring since he reads off from slides. Do the homework though since the contents may appear on the midterm and finals which affects a lot on your grade. He does give you a second chance if you messed up one of your midterms if you do well on your finals which can help boost your grade.

His lectures are extremely thorough and great at helping you learn the material. Tests are 90% of your grade, but follow his lectures and do the homework/understand it, and you'll do great on the exams.

I don't know why he has bad reviews, his lectures are in depth and easy to follow. He posts notes and has pre recorded lectures in case you miss anything. Tests are easier than homework questions which test your knowledge more, only thing is that 90% of your grade comes from two midterms and a final.

I think he is good person and good professor, but the TA's are BAD and don't want to help, except Ryuto. 
The exams are so messy and there it is difficult to follow and you will definitely loose all points on a question if you didn't get the whole answer right, so no partial credit( TA's choose to give/not give partial credit).
Lectures were heavy and I didn't feel like the theory was properly enforced. Midterm(s) and a final, as well as weekly homework. One of my worst experiences unfortunately.

I thoroughly enjoyed this class and felt that Professor Dillencourt was much better than people seem to think. The grading scheme is quite test heavy, but they are easy (everything is straight off of the slides). He is also very friendly and accessible during office hours.

Many people have a bad experience with this professor, but I believe his lectures actually explain the concepts really well. However, he did change this class this quarter and we only had 3 tests instead of 3 tests and 2 quizzes so there was more pressure on us. However, as long as you study his slides and know the concepts well, you'll be fine.

Prof Dillencourt doesn't deserve such a low rating imo. His lectures are one of the clearest I had in UCI, and he's also very kind and accessible outside of class. In fact I think he's one of the most caring profs in UCI. The hw is easy tho, and I feel like I'm not challenged enough. But overall a great prof!

2 Quizzes, 2 Midterms, 1 Final. He does drop scores, but it's done slightly differently - you can bomb both quizzes or 1 Midterms roughly. Almost entirely lecture based. Focus on the nuts and bolts of the algorithms: how they work and the step-by-step. He provides lecture recordings, and attendance wasn't mandatory.

Dillencourt is pretty verbose in lectures & announcements but the material is very clear, making no assumptions about topics from prereq courses by briefly reexplaining them. 5 tests (1 dropped) make up 95% of the grade; they weren't too difficult, but they weigh a lot, so be cautious. (p.s. Dillencourt's voice would be AMAZING for Audible)

This class was the easiest class I've ever taken. Except for the first test I aced every single exam, including the final. The lectures are clear and he explains everything very well. The class was so easy that I doubt it prepared me for future upper divs. If you study the slides/lectures in detail and review the hw and tests you will be golden.
Super boring lectures. Tests account for most of the grade. Take other professors instead imo.

His class is test-heavy (90% of grade from 5 tests) but tests are based on notes. His strength is in his lectures. My gosh, his lectures were some of the clearest and most concise I have ever had the pleasure of watching. For 161, he is the best there is for the course. Everything just makes so much sense and is explained so thoroughly.

Boring lectures, but he explains the material really well. EASY exams. The HW is so much harder. The best thing about his class is the grade cutoffs. You can get a B- with a 70% in the class. I've never had a class with grade cutoffs as low as this class. I did ok in the class, but I still got a high grade. Drops lowest exam score. Take him.

Although boring, he is one of the best lecturers Ive ever had. Tests were very much fair, just based off of his slides. The only thing is his hw can be tough and time consuming, though its provided to help you understand the material and its only worth roughly 10% of your grade (varies each quarter). Overall I find him to be underrated

HW every week. Test every 2 weeks usually on topics from the past 2 HWs except for last test. Class was chill cuz as long as you understand the lectures and HW, the tests aren't bad. if youre lost, ask questions in discussion. I only bombed the first test but thankfully lowest one is dropped. Dillencourt is very reasonable

Dillencourt is very clear in his lecture videos and explains everything slowly but carefully. If you study his example problems from lectures and the homework assignments very well then the tests should not be too much of a problem.

For online CS161 he is without a doubt the best. He explains things clearly and his lectures do not go overtime (generally about 30 minutes total over 2-3 videos). His exams are fair and not time-crunched at all. Homework can be tedious at times but you get a drop. Also, you drop a test so you do not have to take the final.

Underrated. He is actually one of the best professors in upper division. Mostly graded by tests but they are definitely doable by just studying the slides and knowing how to do the basic problems of the homework. Super clear about everything and responsive on piazza. Very solid professor. It's a good class.

161 is a difficult class, but Dillencourt makes it bearable. His lectures are really, really bland, but he posts slides, and almost everything can be found there. The homework is also pretty difficult at first, and they're always a time commitment, but they're nothing insane. All I keep thinking in this course is "it could have been a lot worse."

Bland lectures, but super clear with everything explained in detail. If you can do the homework, you can do the tests easily. Fair grading although I think he made his class easier spring quarter. Very communicative with students.

Super underrated professor. His lectures were really clear and concise. He explains materials really well and he goes through questions during lectures! There were around 6 homework assignments, and tests were really doable as long as you follow his study guide. One homework and final can be dropped.
Good professor, underrated. Take him

Dillencourt's lectures can be kind of bland, but his lecture notes are very detailed, and his exams are extremely doable if you follow the lecture notes and homework. He is compassionate and made lots of thing easier for students for spring 2020 qtr. He curves generously. No coding hw, 4-5 hw's that each take 2-3 hw's to do, and several exams.

He's underrated. His monotone voice is useful if you won't a no BS introduction to algorithms which is really appreciated if you're interested in the subject. This isn't elementary school where you need an excited teacher to teach the subject. This guy knows how to break down complex material in a concise manner. A real gem at UC Irvine imo..
He is not a caring teacher. He only does his job that is broadcasting his lecture notes during the lecture, but thats it,nothing else. So dont expect too much from this class.
He gave to much freedom to his teaching assistant. Terrible teaching assistant couldnt even explain things well. He cannot explains things clearly as well. Try to avoid taking his class.
He doesnt communicate, he only tech. I mean he only saying he only say the words that seems make sure, but he doesnt actually teach. Maybe he is a good computer scientist, but not a great lecturer.
He will test you something way beyond the level of his material. Be prepared. He also gave lousy explanation of the class concept.

Not a good lecturer. His version of this class is also poorly paced (it's way too slow, does not cover important stuff), and dynamic programming is squeezed into Week 10 rather than in Week 5 like the other professors do. Exams are meh, mainly based off the slides. Very little focus on algorithm design, too much on pre-existing algorithm mechanics

Dillencourt isn't terrible, just mediocre. For lectures, he just reads his slides -- don't bother attending. His exams are based purely on the slides, something which he doesn't convey (leading to a 60% average on the first midterm and 90% average on the second once people got it). Curve is generous, albeit unusually complex in computation.

Memorize his slides because that is what the exams test you on, not understanding. The curve is generous so just do your best to memorize his slides for the test and you'll pass. Textbook does little to help you since the tests are slide memorization tests, despite his strong recommendation to do practice problems and read.

Reads off slides. Un-engaging lectures. Dillencourt has poor topic coverage, wasting the 2-3 weeks on review material and squeezing in DP at the end and skipping key topics. Doesn't focus very well on the algorithm "Design" aspect of the class. Exams mainly focus on algorithm mechanics. Final a bit harder than the midterms and was heavy on DP.

CS161 is a hard course, in general. Dillencourts lectures are boring but hes a smart guy. His midterms are fair, but I felt like the final was very difficult and didnt have a fair distribution of questions (essentially 80% of the course was not on there)

Midterms are okay (short answer questions), his slides are poor, so get ready to read the textbook and watch YouTube video to teach yourself. Final (20 multiple choice questions and 5 short answer questions) much harder than midterms.

Reads off slides, which are usually decent. Dry lectures, but if you actually pay attention, he's decent at explaining things. Not amazing, but def not bad either. Also, he seems like he cares a bit, which is more than most profs. Tests are based off hws/lec slides, and are fair. No surprises in this class: everything is "okay" about it.

The material isn't too hard. As long as you understand the slides/textbook, then you'll pass. My problem is that his lecture is very dry and was useless to me. Also, his homework grading system is annoying. My biggest complaint, the homework is unnecessarily "hard" in a way where it's complicated and unhelpful for exams and actually learning...
Strangest homework grading system ever. Don't take

I'm giving this professor this rating not because the "class is hard". It's supposed to be. But let's be honest here, his lectures were just plain boring. It wasn't fine. Every sentence gets quieter and dies off near the end. He rushes through huge concepts that needs to be reapplied on variation for tests. Good difficulty for class, terrible lecs.

Prof. Dillencourt gets harsher ratings than he deserves, likely from students who are in the camp of "I thought CS would be just learning how to write code and then I'd graduate with a six figure salary ezpz" Curves are generous and the final replaces a midterm grade if you do better. His lectures can be dry but he explains everything very well.

The tests are pretty easy (especially the Finals). Class has been highly enjoyable. I do wish that there were pop quizzes related to the tests were given though. It would have helped me kinda now which topics to focus on more instead of making sure I understand every single concept. Regardless, still an easy A if you put some time into it.

Lets be fair here, tests are really easy. Everything he tested are demonstrated in detail on this slides. If you actually studied, you are guaranteed at least a B after curve. As comments mentioned, this is compsci, this is upper div, this is 161. What do you expect? An easy A like ICS31?

Teacher lectures fine... The curve is great, and the questions on the tests are very easy. Reading the slides and attending class helped me do very well on the tests. The reviews below fail to mention how well-distributed the curve is. Computer Science is supposed to be hard -- this is upper division ladies and gentlemen. I'll probably have an A.

Pros: * Tests are easy (low # of questions, simple concept questions) * Slides are good * Teacher introduced me to kewl things Cons: * Homework is a lot harder than the tests (but this helps reinforce your knowledge). The average is quite low, but in my humble opinion I don't exactly think that's the course's/teacher's fault.

Easiest class I ever had in UCI. Tests are 90% of the grade, which is a good thing because the tests are all easy As. What I really hope is that, instead having the 10% of hw, maybe he should give us pop quizzes in lecture.
He's a very smart guy but his lectures are quite boring, and his tests are like "surprise! didn't expect that did you?". No practice exams, and the final is 45% of your grade. GL

Extremely unorganized. Can't seem to get his head straight. Skips through details and jumps to result, but expects you to know everything in tests. HW are just random challenges that don't help at all. Really shouldn't be teaching upper-division classes. Wait for a quarter, he probably won't teach this class consecutively. Otherwise, God bless you.
