The structure of the class can be intimidating. Your entire grade consists of midterm and final. However, the grading is reasonable and the lab exams aren't terribly difficult if you've honestly worked through the lab assignments (which can be quite lengthy). She explains the material very well. Like any class, interest in the subject helps.

The class itself is fair game. Labs are ungraded, but you must know them well to do well on the in-lab exams. Material is very difficult if you don't care about the subject. As for El Zarki herself, while she can be condescending, she is quite helpful and very knowledgeable. Her lectures are pretty clear and not too boring either.

This is a rewarding class you take to really learn. CS132 teaches you bits and pieces of networking, and this class teaches you how the internet operates by putting everything together. El Zarki is an intelligent professor who explains concepts very clearly. CS133 is a pretty hard class but well worth it if you're interested in the subject.

Labs are not mandatory and require some time to read through and successfully complete. However, if you know how the labs work you should be fine on the quizzes. If you don't do the labs then quizzes will be difficult. It helps if you are genuinely interested in computer networking, otherwise you might just be slugging it out for a whole quarter

Professor El Zarki was amazing, but ONLY if you take the time to care about the class. It is extremely difficult and many that take it hate it on the sole basis that it focuses heavily on technical aspects. Great class if you want to learn
Avoid if you can.. you dont go to this class to learn.. you basically need to know everything by yourself.

This is NOT just a lab course! The labs are fun(if you're lucky to get a working computer)but the report takes FOREVER to complete! Anything you do or learn in the labs will not save your soul from the exams. She is a HARSH grader, so don't expect sympathy. If you have any other options, I suggest you go that route. I could go on but char limit...
Projects are not hard but midterm/final are. Not hard to get a B+ or A- . She is a very insincere person.

This is my 3rd time taking a course with Professor Wang, and my views of him have not changed. His class is laughably easy; CS 177 is basically statistics all over again, plus other things you might have learned from other classes (e.g. Markov Chains). I have gained a bit more respect for him, however... he is patient and understanding.

Wang is a good teacher. Make sure to pay attention in class. For CS132, do read the book sometimes and make sure you know stuff. It's not as easy as his other classes. Class was fun and very educational. 132 has a good bit of memorization as well.

The main problem I had with this class is the structure. He moves through volumes of material at a quick pace and doesn't go into too much detail, so most of the learning is done through the textbook. Last 4 weeks of class are group presentations that no one cares about. Why structure this way? Spend more time explaining important concepts instead.
Creates unnecessarily difficult midterms then makes it so that your finals count for 50% of your grade

Hardest class I had to take at UCI. Professor makes the course unnecessarily harder than it should be. The final exam made up 50% of the final grade which is very unfair and dismisses all the other assignments like midterms, quiz, and homework.
Worst professor I've had in 3 years, and I've had some pretty bad professors
Terrible professor. Avoid this guy if you can.

Out of my 3 years at UCI so far, Prof. Hirschberg is the worst professor I've ever had. He's the opposite of caring. 161 is supposed to be a super hard course, but he makes it harder. He wants to make the material on tests a surprise. The only thing I like about this course is that it is now over. It was a struggle, & I studied hard.

Rumors did not do this class justice, everything you have heard is true. AVOID AT ALL COSTS, TAKE ANYONE ELSE. -very hard hw that doesn't help prepare for tests -quizzes ez, but no partial credit, so can't make any mistakes -slides all in formal math, he doesn't explain simply, so makes impossible to understand. -don't take unless robot (srs)
Dan Hirschberg is horrible, don't take him, disappointed in the UC system for hiring him.

How to SURVIVE in this class: read slides; do homework; attend discussions, where TAs are ready to translate what the professor says in his class into understandable normal English; and finally, however you study (slides, books, Google,...), be sure to understand the topics covered in this class, because this class is cumulative.

TRU ALGORITHMS WARRIOR. LIVES BY THE CODE OF ALGORITHMS, FORMAL THEORY AND MATH. Great if you are going to get your PHD in formal math, this guy is a true believer. If you are a normal person, be prepared to take the L.

Avoid, all theory, very few applied examples. No partial credit on quizzes, 1 mistake and it's a zero, a little bit given on tests. Grading scheme compounds the difficulty of this already difficult class.
Lectures, Homework, and Tests don't seem to have very much to do with each other. Lectures are particularly random and give you little knowledge on how to do the homework.
Questions given In his exams are very confusing. And his exams are not relevant to homework and quizs. He does not explain the confusing parts In his exams. Good Computer scientist. Bad Professor.

Course is tough, but go into this one especially with an open mind. You will get D's on your exams if you prepare in an average way. To not do this, be sure to attend lecture + discussion. Learn what every algorithm does, know it's complexity, go over homework and practice implementing dynamic and recursive algorithms. You should be good. Good prof

Normally Algorithm course is hard in any university teaching. So never think this course as easy A. You will meet lots of reading, homework, tough exams. But if you follow all steps you will learn a lot! Professor is respected and intelligent, if you could not follow his lecture in class it is normal. The only thing you should do is self-learn.

His lectures are so boring, he usually has a slide full of pseudocode on the screen.  I can't pay attention to him for more than a minute. A majority of the topics he covers in lecture will not be on the exams. If you really want to succeed in this class, go to every discussion section, that's where the real learning and note taking takes place.

He is a good professor and he knows his material well. However, his class is very tough. His homework is very hard, so if you can solve them then you should get A+. The quiz is solely based on the material in lecture, so that's good. The midterm, on the other hand, is nightmare. Either be genius or very creative to pass the class, or fail miserably

This course is very thought-provoking and inspirational. It definitely broadens your knowledge about algorithms and data structures (in object-oriented programming, that is). You will have to think about how to test / debug your programs in order to get full credit in correctness. Start early and design multiple prototypes.

Go to every class and you'll learn everything! Great lecturer just pay attention and do the reading beforehand. Not sure why everyone is complaining, this is an important class for CS students and fundamental!
Homework was almost useless. Lectures were dry and the tests were nearly impossible. To make matters worse, there was no curve. Make sure to take another professor, looks like I'm going to have to :

He gives clear lectures and his assignments for HW can really help you learn the material. However his tests are nothing like what he teaches in class. Even if you understand the course throughout the quarter, the tests are nothing like anything seen in class. They are very tough and you will not get a lot of partial credit.

Dr Hirschberg is a great professor. He's very excited about the subject matter and really encourages students to ask questions. I enjoyed all of his lectures and found them to be very clear. I highly recommend him.

whenever you answer or question something in class, he gives responses that makes as if he didn't want to hear anything from the student. lectures are unclear and unnecessarily fast paced. don't take this guy ever.

The commenters here are right, Hirschberg's classes are tough but everyone should take CS165 with him before graduating. I had to work my ass off but it was extremely rewarding and the class made me finally learn C/C++. The projects are long and hard but they are also interesting. I did not get an A but I have no regrets. It was a true CS class.

Seriously the hardest CS class I've taken so far. The subject itself is tough, but the professor just makes it so much worse. He is unclear and fast in lecture, and is condescending to students who ask & answer questions. I've always gotten A's or A+ in my CS classes before and thought I could handle this guy, even from the bad reviews. Nope.

First four weeks on Zoom weren't the best - he's a great teacher, but struggled a lot with Zoom and writing on a tablet for class. His in-person class is great - Professor Vazirani explains difficult concepts in simple terms and engages the class so that lectures aren't just him talking. Beware of his exams though...

Made it clear from the first week that 95% of our grade is exams with the final being a whole 50% of our grade. Lectures are disorganized and don't follow any plan. Nobody can read his messy-cursive handwriting. Has no syllabus or plan for the rest of the quarter either. The 5% homework is just problems from the textbook. Don't take him!

He teaches you exactly what you need to know to do all the parts of the projects. Pay attention to his drawings and his pseudocode. Also tells you exactly what you need to show for each project in the rubric. Teaching staff also very responsive and quick to grade
Class is based upon 5 projects. Attend his lectures and you will be able to do the projects easily. Really easy A, especially for an upper division CS course. He also is really good lecturer.
Tony is just an awesome professor and person. He's one of those ones that you wish can adopt you. You all know what I mean. Guys?

The projects are fair and easy. Professor is really chill. But this is a project course and the final was worth 40%. It was medium difficulty, and you could easily lose A in the class because of this.
You'll have so much extra credit by the end that you can absolutely tank the final and still get an A. Professor is more than fair and passionate about teaching.

Such a cool and funny guy. Lectures can be dull but he tries his best to entertain. Goes over labs in great detail. First one was hard just to connect board, but lab hours were big help. Second lab complex, and then the rest were pretty easy. Free zybooks points, ec offered on labs. Final was hard but not worth much, 65 and still got A in class

Enjoyed his lectures as they are pretty important to learn or understand the class, but the projects are reasonable and are the majority of the grade making it a relatively easier class. Only downsides were how expensive it can be (like 100 per person in a pair). Great class overall despite that

Very easy class. If you only show up to the 4-6 lectures where he talks about the projects, you're almost guaranteed an A. He pretty much just tells you how to do the projects in those lectures which makes completing them very easy. The homework is just reading an online textbook called ZyBooks which is free points. The final was also very simple.

One of the easiest CS classes at UCI. It was quite boring for the most part, though. His lectures are dry and pretty useless except for the days he talks about the projects. The projects are spoonfed to you, and most of them take little time to complete if you go to those lectures. He seems like a good guy, but this class is overrated imo.
make sure to go to all classes
must go to ALL lectures but exams are not difficult if you pay attention during lectures. lab consumed a lot of outside time. not a bad class overall.

Took both discussion and labs for this course. Tony & the TA (his own student) made the experience fun and enjoyable. I was somewaht interested in embedded systems and after taking this course I have a clearer picture of the industry. Tony is the best professor I've had yet and extremelty enthusiastic in this field of computing.
DO NOT take it if this is your last quarter at UCI. He will reports your grades late. After the final, you will lose contact with him forever, and you will receive an NR on your transcript.

He is an incredibly knowledgeable professor on artificial intelligence and is also very caring and understanding. He also structures his class in a way that it is very easy to succeed. He is a bit monotone but that really doesn't matter. If you could learn this subject with anyone, I'd definitely recommend him.

Well, I should have dropped this class after the first day of the class. For 10 weeks, I didn't think I could understand the material at all. Going to his office hour did not help the fact that I did bad on quizzes despite tons of practices. He expected us to read the book, but the book was math-heavy to the extent it was not approachable at all.

Lectures are boring but professor is really kind. Grade is 4 quizzes (lowest dropped), midterm, final, partnered project, and discussion attendance. Project is fairly simple but will take some time. Exams are near identical to previous exams, and he gives access to all previous exams and quizzes. Very flexible as well. Recommend!

i usually do not say this often, but this class was waste of my time that i wished i would have attend a different class that i actually would learn something, horrible just read from confusing notes, boring, and the materials is just so dry or he makes them so dry, either one but ya i regret taking this class. if i could rate him 0 i would

His lectures could put a meth house to sleep. Extremely boring, making it nearly impossible to follow. Gee, whiz. A lot of studying on your own. He provides all old tests/quizzes which allows you to be very prepared.

Very dry and boring lectures. He's a really nice guy though, and more than fair when adjusting exam grading to account for typos/ambiguities, etc. Exams are extremely easy given they're practically identical to the previous years' (he gives tons of practice quizzes/exams). Project is interesting.

Don't take if you struggle with attention. I'm serious, he's the Dyson Dryer. He is a wonderful man and caring. He does his best as best he can. He is willing to humiliate himself to help teach. Plenty of practice exams and quizzes. Great man, but you will be seriously challenged to pay attention. Coffee alleviated the symptoms. His efforts are A+

Lectures were boring & went too fast to fully understand. Studied for the quizzes/midterm/final by repeatedly doing the past quizzes/exams; which were VERY VERY helpful. The class project wasn't much of an "AI" project - but you DO need time to set time aside to do it (i.e. don't procrastinate).

If you ask if the class is curved he says you should of worked harder and studies longer yet he makes mistakes on tests and doesnt even make his own slides. Maybe if HE worked harder he would be a better teacher.

The lectures can be a bit dry be he's always willing to take questions and is very receptive to student feedback. Fast replies on piazza. Tons of past quizzes to study off of and you'll be okay for the most part if you actually take the time to study them. Project was fairly easy too.

Very boring lectures and not a class you get much out of. I studied his previous quizzes and exams religiously (posted on his canvas) and would master them, but this quarter he always sprung us with a few random questions that I wasn't prepared for. Program project was fairly easy, slow grading

CS 171 was an easy class with Lathrop. His lectures were only hard to follow because they were boring, not because they were hard. Very easy class, 4 quizzes (drop lowest), a midterm, and a final + a project. He provides you with so much past material for you to study off of, which is great! Makes studying for exams easy and there are no surprises

Lathrop has way more good features than bad. Yes, his lectures can be quite dull, but most of his class is based on quizzes, midterm, assignments, and final. I don't see how anyone can fail his class because he literally gives you YEARS of old quizzes/midterms/finals to study off of and ends up using nearly the same questions. Good, caring prof.
Rude to students, lectures are super boring, doesn't like answering questions. Lectures are pretty much useless.
boring lecture, super helpful via email and office hours, fun projects, easy tests, he does not curve , practice previous tests you wont learn much, dense lecture ,

No professor and course combination can match it. Perfectly clear instructions with tests and papers from previous years. 1 amazing and fun project. 4 quizzes that are fair and easy to study for. 1 midterm and final that are pretty similar to the quizzes. If you have the choice to take him just take it blindly. This class is a no-regret and fun.

One of the best professors at UCI. Gives the tests for the past 10 years, so you don't have to worry about them and can actually learn. The project is interesting (and easy once you understand it) and you actually do use the concepts you learn in class. As long as you go through the lecture slides and do the past tests, you'll be fine!

Not difficult, but straightforward to a fault. Lectures are unhelpful. To do well on exams: review old exams, textbook, sometimes lecture slides. Provides all old quizzes and exams, which are close to the actual tests. Project can be time-consuming, but not too hard. Very clear about class logistics. Actually, too clear - sends many, many emails.

Finally a professor where you pretty much 90% know whats going to be on the test. Lots and lots of practice exams that VERY VERY closely resemble the test. Project was, as I understand it, harder than previous years - so get that project done ASAP. His advice to all grade-related things is Study harder, but you pretty much know whats onTheTests

He is honestly one of the best professors at UCI, or in fact any University. He genuinely takes time to help his students and has designed a course that actually teaches the course content brilliantly. Everything he teaches is applied to the class project which is one of the best college projects I've ever done.

Really nice and fair professor that genuinely cares about students. Responds to emails quickly and exam/quiz questions are similar to past exams. (Do all of them.) Average overall grade was 92%. Lectures can be boring but practicing old exams gets you far.. Also he is funny in his own goofy way. Start the coding assignment early.

Don't let his very deep, monotone voice deceive you - this class is the easiest class at UCI I have taken that I thought would be pretty hard. Easy project, easier tests. Easy A! Oh, and lectures (and discussion) are optional. If you want 4 easy units without showing up to lecture, here you go.
easiest class ever. Quizzes/Midterm/Final appear EXACTLY as previous year Tests or previous quizzes. easy professor, great TA. he even hints test questions during lecture. GET HIM FOR AI

Professor Tsudik was actually a good and funny professor compared to what these review say. Maybe it was because the class was online, he really focused on explaining the lecture material and since they were recorded, I was able to rewatch them to get a good score on the final. Midterm was difficult but fair and final was surprisingly very generous
Dont cheat, and use the TAs as much as you can and youll be fine.

Professor Tsudik is really only good (sometimes) at talking about his topic. He could probably care less about whether the students actually learn, retain, or are reinforced by any of the material. Lecture slides are hard to follow, material doesn't transfer well to homework, and the TAs are vague at best and care about the same as the professor.

Good luck, You'll most likely fail the midterm and final, not kidding. Do well on the 3 HW assignments, they'll give you a buffer. HW Assignments are short but insanely difficult also. Don't bother googling the questions, they aren't there. Generous curve at the end (depending on how class is doing but majority of class will fail)
This class is really hard, but the curve was really generous (about 20% curve). Make sure to get as many points as you can on the homework so your grade can tank the exams. Insanely dense course.

worst class I've ever taken - slides are vague - homework is so vague to the point where the TAs and graders make assumptions that aren't mentioned within the question so there is no clue what is right or wrong - midterm and final consist of 90% questions that aren't on homework or practice exams whatever you do, do not take this class
Class experience: you Learn how to read during lecture. Then, the homework and tests ask you to write a Nobel Prize-winning level novel.
How bad he is ? Went to TA's office hour to ask a question on the sample final. TA told us that question might be his joke.??? SO which part is more important? Joking or serious teaching?

slides are terrible. He excepts you know everything but he doesn't tech you or even give any guidelines to learn. The class has no discussion and no online question board to ask questions. As a student, you basically on your own. He made too many unnecessary joke during the lectures to wasting class time. Worst class experience.
The hardest course I've taken at UCI. Slides are terrible.

Lectures. Aren't. Helpful. Your lecture slides will be bare-bones, and even if you understand the higher level concept of what is being taught, it won't apply to the homework (you have 3, and you're graded by sadists) because you'll be expected to give a level of detail not even covered in class, and you'll lose massive points for it. It's a mess

He is a sarcastic and funny guy, but I had a lot of trouble understanding what he is saying. The jump from lecture to homework is very large, and the TAs aren't very helpful. He does not give a lot of guidance for studying for the tests, and many students fail. Tests are very hard and answers are not given so it's hard to learn from mistakes.

His midterm have 120 point in total. The average is 45, the standard deviation is 20.96. Seriously?? Always intimidate the class that he would failed the whole class if he need to. All the TAs are not helpfully. They seems have the same ideology of the professor. Really arrogant.

He explained to you all those really high level things during lectures and doesnt prepare us for the hw at all. Confused lecture slices and always like to scare students which is a big downside for taking his class. Its so easy to lost in his class!!

Tsudik knows how to keep the class engaged by cracking jokes frequently. Concepts are abstract but digestible if you attend lecture. Hard midterm but the second half of the quarter was relatively easy. Very knowledgeable professor and enjoys questions from students. By far most entertaining professor at UCI

Tsudik's satire becomes a bit too much at times, to the point where it even spills into his midterm and final. Homework assignments are fair and possible to do well on, but the midterm and final will make you cry.  The class is not easy and definitely makes you think outside of the box of basic network security.

His slides are very condensed and confusing. He's unclear on how much you need to know some topics because of the lack of assigned readings and the slide on the topic is very condensed and unclear. Reading the optional course book and  research on course material is advised. But how in-depth you should know the material is unclear.

Wow, Tsudik is the best troll I've had the pleasure to have at UCI. He is quite hilarious, and just when you think he's going to stumble with his jokes they continually get better. Difficult problems, study the slides, READ THE BOOK (it's about accessible and as hilarious as Tsudik). See the TA, and hopefully you should get a C-.

The topics of the class are interesting and relevant but the prof doesn't do a good job at keeping your attention in lecture. He also has very unclear project and grading requirements. Lectures are not going to help you do your project, you have to learn it on your own.

Full mobile application to write along with the worst written midterm I'd ever seen in my four years here. Final was a bit better after everyone complained on Piazza. Rubric for the application wasn't given until week 9. Avoid at all costs.

Open wikipedia page on "dual quaternion" and start reading. That pretty much how lectures are. Just a ton of insanely dense material with no stop talking. Very little direction as to what the main takeaways are. He has you for 20min after that its just too much to stay with him. 50+ slides per lecture, all densely packed. Lots of papers/project.
Take this class if you think you can finish writing a complete mobile app within a few weeks

He is a well-respected person in his field. The class is organized based on his thoughts about Search Systems, not a book. His lectures are great, but his voice is very soothing and can make you sleepy. For the project, make sure you have a good team. The project is open-ended, so try to finish a well-rounded one.

Ramesh Jain.. what can I say. Class is alright as long as you and your partners know what you're doing for your project. It's pretty open ended so the sky is the limit. This also does mean the class is pretty disorganized but that's not really a bad thing. Study the questions at the end of the slides because they will be the on the final and MT.

The reviews don't lie, this class is extremely disorganized. No requirements until the project is pretty much due. The homework is absolutely pointless and wont help for the tests or anything for that matter.
This class is easy, all you need to memorize is the 4 V's of big data

Awful, awful class. This is the worst class I have ever taken. It's a project course, but there is a midterm, 4 homework assignments, and a final. The professor gave us a list of over 300 questions to study from. Absolutely ridiculous. Also, the project was very vague. He didn't tell us the project requirements until almost the very end.

Terrible. Most disorganized class I've ever taken. CS125 is a project course, but he gives you 6 weeks to build a full application, do user studies, write a report, and prepare a demo. On top of that, you have to keep up with homeworks and tests. Even more ridiculous is he gives the project rubric at WEEK 9. Do yourself a favor, and don't take it.

This is an awful class. Other people are not lying when they said do not take this class. There is one big project for the entire course and there is no clear project guideline! The requirements for the project were extremely vague.

Prof has super vague project specifications. And by vague I mean none. There are not project specifications but marks you down for things that weren't even mentioned. Homework is vague and you are marked off for things that weren't even in the questions. Would not recommend.

Do yourself a favor and don't take this course. Can't understand his accent, can't hear him as he speaks softly, course is EXTREMELY unstructured and unorganized. All the content on his lecture powerpoints are acquired from the internet- he doesn't create his own content. To study for his exams, he tells his students to "Search on the internet!"

He's not a bad professor when teaching the class. But he is bad for allowing students to use their laptops on the final exam. Please don't make the mistake that I did for not having a laptop. If you don't have one, buy one. It is your ticket for a guarantee A+ on the final exam. That is why I gave him a 5 on easiness.
Pretty straightforward in his powerpoints.  If you pay attention in class and read from the book, you should do just fine.  He's a really nice, helpful guy.

HW 30% and is doable. Midterm 30% with an avg 65%, test problem is tricky and hard. Final is 40%. Test problems are much harder than HWs. This is one of those class you have to learn 15weeks materials within 10 weeks.

Lectures were often useless, but not sure whether it's the professor or whether it's the material. Professor very nice though. Read and stay ahead in the textbook readings, otherwise you will be lost. There are 4 homeworks problem sets, midterm, and final. The exams are very hard; have to know homework problem sets inside out, avg's 65.

I kind of liked the guy. He really wanted the students to learn. The issue was it was his first time teaching and he was a bit inexperienced. I think he will get better as an instructor since he had the knowledge. HWs are doable, exams are tough but lots of partial credit. I think coming quarters he would be better. I would give him another chance.
His lectures are terrible and he's disrespectful to students. He responds on Piazza with irrelevant information. The HW isn't that bad. The tests are a mess.

some professors are good lecturers. some assign homework problems and tests related to lecture material. some are actually nice and care about their students. some may fit more than one of these categories, maybe all three. bouloukakis fits absolutely zero of those categories.

This is the worst professors I've had, and I've had some REALLY bad ones. The guy looks down at students, one could even say disrespectful. He assigns HWs with very limited instructions and grades you extremely harshly on it. The exams are irrelevant to HWs and lectures and are very tough. Lectures are a waste of life

First impressions? Condescending. Immediately made the class unlikable and it only went downhill from there. Lectures, homework, and exams, are all irrelevant to each other and it becomes extremely confusing in regards to what we should study for. His attitude sucks when answering questions. All we can do is pray that there is at least a curve.
Did not learn anything relevant. Slides are useless; everyone bombed the midterm. Lectures are boring and not worth going to. Avoid this professor!

Tests take a huge chunk of your grade. They're hard and you don't have a cheat sheet like previous classes always had. Lectures are OK, he mainly tells you to read the textbook so you can pass. I guess lectures don't mean anything.

Professor does not give good lectures, misleads students on what will be on the exams, and has horrible communication skills. Homeworks, lectures and self study does not prepare you for his exams. Genuinely the worst professor I've taken at UCI. Highly recommend taking another professor.

No office hours w/o appointment. Not allowed to email him or TAs. Piazza only. Homework is doable, but worth very little, albeit heavily graded on accuracy. Test does not represent homework or discussion, it's much harder. He took the little given practice work and made it extremely complex. Seems 70% bombed. Take at own risk.

trade-off between having a grade scale that makes it hard to fail but nearly impossible to get an A. The downside is the quality of the lectures. Lectures are hard to follow and not engaging (though he'll ask questions). HW & tests toughly graded - slashes points off easily w/o making clear details so avg grade on a HW is 50-60 out of 100. nvr agn
My journey in this class is not over yet.
When I heard that he curves a 28% to D- that was pretty cool. Besides that the class is pretty hard to follow and the textbook is garbage. If you don't care about GPA this class is legit.
Mercy
His lectures has 0 value to attend. You better off using those time to read the book.

His lecture slides are either from textbook or from other websites and his homework is also borrowed from Alex. He barely answers questions and his exam questions sucks (at least his 45j midterm and final, yeah, I took his 45j and 141). He can not teach you anything but only confuses you. I am wandering why he can a university professor.

Honestly, Zhenping Wu is the only qualified professor at UC Irvine to teach computer science. His assignments are so fair and his exams are a piece of cake. I visit his office hours weekly; he's such a sweetheart when you get to know him! Although I am currently failing the class with a D, I will definitely take more classes with him in the future.
He made Klefstad look like a good instructor

Worst professor I have experienced. I've never felt like I have learned nothing in a course before but CS141 with Wu is the closest thing to it. He puts no effort into producing course material and is unable to explain it in lecture. Assignments are very ambiguous and he will not answer questions about them. Avg. assignment scores are in the 50s.

I usually make it my civic duty to rate my professors, whether they do good or bad. Wu is bad. Very bad. Of all the things he does as a lecturer, he simply doesn't teach. Going to his lectures doesn't help you at all. It's difficult to discern whether he knows what he's doing since his lectures come down to circling slides arbitrary slides.
If you have even the slightest alternative option to take another professor, do it.

I never have a class where everyone worked together on the midterm prepare doc the whole day till 1 and not even finish. I never have to study this much and still so confused. Only from professor Wu class, where I find magic red circle, ambiguous homework, average F on two homework, little help from professor and TA.
I would rather delay my graduation than take a class with him.
Horrible.

I loved Franklin's off topic anecdotes about computing, it makes the lectures far more tolerable. While the quizzes are difficult in the time given, they are directly from the assigned and SUGGESTED homework problems. All of the homework and quiz questions are short answer,but he rarely gives partial credit. Helpful at office hours,but not in lect.

like the other people have said, his quizzes are extremely hard and time consuming, 20 mins is NOT enough. quiz questions dont make sense most of the time, very ambiguous in what hes looking for. TA was not helpful at all.

Possiby the worst professor I've ever encountered at UCI. His quizzes are lengthy, and only gives you 20 minutes to complete them (trust me, the time runs out pretty quickly). Doesn't give u an extra second on them either. Doesn't grade on a curve. The final was a nightmare! Bottom line, avoid if you can.

Avoid at all costs. The slides are very dense and he does a poor job of explaining difficult concepts. Very unapproachable and rude, especially in office hours. The midterm was extremely difficult (average was an F). The TA was 100% much more helpful in making sure we understood the concepts and always answered our questions whenever we had any.

The course is interesting, but the professor makes it more difficult than necessary. Expects you to know every detail of a topic. Seems indifferent to the success of the students and at times made condescending  comments about the class. Expected the class to find a security flaw in 1 minute that took researchers years to discover.

Coming from a family of computer scientists and years of experience with Computers she literally makes me want to switch majors. She just reads off of the slides she is given online and is no help whatsoever.
Just read off the slides. Easy to deal with test since she just takes the tests from other school and use them directly.

Don't take this professor if you want to save your GPA. Clearly nervous when lecturing, does not seem even slightly interested in topics, does not teach at all and only reads off slides word for word. Extremely dull class. HWs are not relevant to the exams, exams are completely and unexpectedly difficult. Expect a lot of self  teaching and reading.

Professor Ramanan is a generous grader. The mode of scores he gave in the presentation was 87.5%. He smiled to us when he taught when we presented. You will need to hand in resume and cover letter for the first week. But don't worry, you will get a chance to change your grade since he provides resume and CV revision. His teaching is logical, too!

this spring quarter he decided to have a 3 hour lecture on the evening of every monday. this was so that group members were at least working on the projects early on in the week, which can be helpful, but time consuming. watch out for deadlines as you dont have a lot of time with the 2nd project due to the server. quizzes are mostly sourceable

Hard to understand, he speaks fast and has a thick accent, so quickly stopped attending lectures. Having a good group will make it a lot easier. Didn't teach any code only pseudo and theory, so a lot of outside research was needed. Despite feeling stressed by this class it was graded very easily by the TAs which is why I still got an A.

Graded by quizzes and project. Flexible class structure. Projects can be fairly difficult and are often vaguely worded. If you have a bad group it can make this course very difficult. Would not recommend unless you have a group of trusted teammates.

Finding a group is mandatory if you want to pass, even though it isn't required. Class is very difficult and definitely changed my opinion of upper-div classes. Mainly graded by two large projects and a few quizzes. Felt like this class is what taught me the most, even though I fumbled the projects by going it solo. Hope I get to take it again!

Great professor, very passionate. Gives you the tools you need to create a search engine. Not very difficult, but lots of work. Projects can be done in groups. 3 projects and 5 quizzes, lowest quiz dropped. Quizzes and final open note. Learned a lot and was fun. No need for attendance, except when presenting code to TAs and final.
Pay attention to lectures, he knows his stuff. Find yourself a good group early on and you will breeze (jk they alot of work) through the projects.

Excellent course and professor. Divided into 3 projects that congeal into a full search engine, and 6 quizzes (1 dropped except the final quiz). Lots of extra credit. Enjoyable content and lectures, passion is clearly there and shines through. Excellent project for learning/resume. Balanced between CS/etc majors for difficulty. Highly recommend!

Really enjoyed Alberto. Very knowledgeable in information retrieval and clearly passionate about it, as well as astronomy (and star trek). This passion really rubs off on you in the best ways. Class was normal level of difficulty, if not a little easier for a CS class to account for INF students like myself. Keep that fire alive prof Alberto!

Project 50%, and 5 quizs 50%, lowest quiz dropped. Finding good teammates REALLY HELPS your grade. Very vague project instruction, you have to figure a lot of things out. Gives extra credit to active piazza student, that's why he and TAs almost don't respond or respond very late on piazza. Lecture quality is solid, I do learn a lot.

CS 121 with Krone-Martins was one of the best if not the best class I've taken at UCI. He is extremely knowledgeable and his lectures are great. He provides slides and notes which are what he bases his quizzes on. The project is a great addition to your resume and overall I learned a ton in this class. Easy class but you learn a lot. Theres EC too.

121 is honestly OK with this professor. The quizzes are tricky at first, but they are get better later on. The projects do not have clear directions, but the grading is not harsh. Overall, this class is ok, not bad. You do learn a lot of useful information too.

Make sure you find a good group for the projects, as they are long and are easier with people. Graded based on quizzes and projects only and he is super lecture heavy which are pretty boring. Lectures which are needed to do the project are also released only 3 days before it is due. Overall pretty challenging class without strong coding skills.

he went over the lecture time by at least 10 minutes everything class. He gave us two lectures to watch the Monday after thanksgiving. He was understanding in the sense he extended the deadline of both major projects. Projects were doable but had lots of parts to them, so having a team and starting early helped a lot.

There are 3 major projects, the first of which is easy to complete and the other two being much more time consuming. However, the lectures are extremely relevant and helpful, and the professor does a great job at conveying all the important concepts. The 5 quizzes during the quarter are also extremely straightforward.
pretty bad at responding to emails. seems like he checks piazza around once a day only? don't expect to learn too much from his lectures. All the projects will be self learning and googling stuff.

The material is challenging, but he did an exceptional job conveying it. If you actively listen during the lectures, you will understand the concepts. He also provides psuedo code that is very helpful for projects. He seems to have a real passion for what he's teaching.

The material isn't very hard. The two main projects were very unspecified and the content of the projects were not taught in time to implement. He changed specifications on the discussion board without them being on the project specification. He was also not accomodating to the COVID or protest situation. In fact, he went against it and curved down

Took him during Winter 2020 where the final was made optional. I personally don't think he deserves a score that low mainly since he is fantastic during his office hour. But beware that this class was not as easy as people said - the concepts were still a bit challenging and the projects would take a while. Also, the quizzes are pretty tricky.

There's 5 projects worth 50% (5 x 10%), 4 quizzes, lowest dropped, worth 25% (4 x 5%), and a final exam worth 25%. He's not active at all on Piazza and is extremely unclear with his instructions and lectures. All of his lectures don't show actual code and expects you to grasp everything.

While the material itself is very dry, he does a decent job conveying it. That being said, if lecture weren't mandatory, I would not have showed up. Apparently, stronger requirements for the web crawler than the other professor teaching 121 during the same quarter. Keep abreast of the slides and the crawler and search engine, and you'll do ok 3.5/5
You make a game as your final project. You have weekly quizzes on the lectures, but they're usually quite easy if you just play the videos in the background.

Nice, easy-going, enthusiastic professor. You make a game w/ur group & do small writing assignments thruout process. Took the class in Fall 2020 (online-pandemic) and we also had a choice to just do a design doc (long) instead of a game. Lecture videos released every week + canvas quizzed on them (more for participation).

Very chill class, he gives lectures on videogame history and a little bit of game design. He is very enthusiastic in his lectures which is pretty awesome and fun to see. But, if you were interested in a class that teaches you how to use the Unity engine or something, you're out of luck since your group has to learn that on your own.

Denenberg is very passionate about games and it shows in his lectures, which were half game history and half game development. He was also very accommodating during the COVID remote learning period and set up a Discord server where you could talk about games and easily reach him for questions.

I absolutely love Denenberg. His lectures are super engaging and interesting, and he actually seems to care more about his students learning the material than memorizing stuff for a grade. This guy also seriously loves video games. He is the perfect professor to teach this class.
He gave us a big curve at the end. Thought we should do the same to him ;-D
He has a very clear grading criteria until he makes he makes even more clear.
He has a large game collection, nothing other than that relate to game development

Lectures are pretty boring but there are some extra credit opportunities to catch up your grade. 3 take-home quizzes but no finals. You group up with 2-4 people and just basically create a mobile health app system.

5 quizzes, some assignments, and a final exam. Assignments have extra credit which help a lot, so make sure to at least attempt some of them. Ibrahim himself is good lecturer and lectures are recorded. Study slides and refer to recordings when you get confused. The last 2 projects, especially the web crawler, are very time consuming so start early.

This class was pretty light. Never showed up to 8am lecture except for the quizzes. Quizzes are easy if open note, but otherwise hard. So it is really dependent on if he is sick or feeling lenient enough. The group project grades are really dependent on which TA you find. Lectures were aight. Overall Ibrahim is super chill but almost too chill.

4 quizzes, some projects, and a final exam. Ibrahim is pretty fair and gives informative lectures with a couple short examples. Some of projects may take longer than you think (due to the runtime), so start early. Project directions can be a bit vague, though it allows your implementation to not be strictly bound to certain requirements.
if coding is not your strong suit, avoid this class as an elective.

Ibrahim is a really fair professor. Fair grading with clear, concise lectures. Lowest quiz grade is dropped and quizzes are reasonable; watch the lectures and read the slides. Projects are time-consuming (and doable alone if you want). If the instructions are unclear, just ask on Piazza. Him and his TAs are super responsive. Overall great prof!

Most people said his 121 class was an easy A and I disagree. Not saying it was extremely hard either but this class took a substantial amount of time for me. Quizzes were fair, it was just the projects that were challenging. Vague directions for them and they take longer than you think even if you work in a group. Good lecturer tho imo

The professor is extremely disorganized,has plenty of typos in his quizzes. He will not even know they are there if people do not ask to see the problems they missed. The project requirements do not include everything they expect,pray you get fair grader/TA. Even after he acknowledging there are unfair grading he does not do anything to fix it.

Super nice and amiable professor with good lectures. 4 quizzes (lowest dropped) are simple Canvas multiple choice and a big final administered on Canvas MC. Homeworks were interesting and definitely took some time, but were fun group projects for building a search engine. Really responsive on Piazza. Highly recommend.

Great lecturer and quite well structured course. VERY IMPORTANT: you're graded by few things. If you mess up one, your grade seriously drops. 8/10 quiz average and almost perfect final, I left with 90 percent. Didn't absolutely study quiz, but I worked it hard for the final. Not many people stayed in class, but I did. I enjoyed it.

He is by far the best teacher I have ever had. He is always willing to help students by looking over what they missed on quizzes and really helpful in explaining concepts. Quizzes are fair and doable if you go to lecture. Assignments arent hard and not time consuming as long as you make sure to dedicate enough time everyday to do them.

It's an amazing course which helps you to build up your knowledge and skills by the interesting lectures and well-designed projects. Professor Ibrahim is very caring, responsible and professional. He always tries his best to make sure that students have understood the lectures and he is always there when you have any questions.

There are four quizzes (drop lowest one), one final and three projects(2 can be grouped). Professor Ibrahim is a very responsible and professional. He replied my email like in 15 mins. Even after class, he is very nice and patient to help me about how to achieve better grade in my quiz by explaining the mistake I made.
What a chill class lol Attendance is optional and quizzes are pretty easy if you read the slides. Assignments are not too hard and you can work in a group of 3. (Solo work is also allowed)

Not hard to get a passing grade at all. However, the grading method is mainly based on opinion. This applies to the ICS 52 course as well. In other words you're not really learning anything. There is 1 benefit I got from CS 113 though, and that is networking with people.

Frost has a knack for making lectures lively, even if the material is boring as hell. His tests, projects, and homework tend to focus on practical applications of the material, rather than memorization of the theoretical definitions. I wish he made the class harder, because the median class scores were always in the high 80s.

This course isn't as bad as what people make it out to be. If you go to class, and listen to his explanations rather than just write down what is on the slides you should do well. The TA recorded his discussions and they were really helpful in completing the homework and the exams mirrored the homework as well.
Grades are based on three homeworks(16% each), one midterm and one final (26% each). Hard homework, fair test.

I think he is still teaching, but when I was trying to add his profile to RMP, it shows something like "Qi Chen has stopped teaching." After check RMP's term, I find this is because he was added before but someone report he no longer teaching. SO, why there is someone report fake info, and who the one is? That's an interesting question.

Class was really difficult, but overall, I thouroughly enjoyed it. The content requires alot of time to understand, so its something you should only take if you are into proofs/math. Homeworks were very difficult, but felt really rewarding once completed. The class is a great experience if you are interested in the content!

Cryptography is just difficult in general. Prof really likes to lecture purely on the whiteboard. Organization of the course is more day-to-day rather than planned well ahead. It was week 2 when the Canvas & Gradescope page were published. Homeworks (70% weight of 3 to 4 HWs) are just announced on a random Saturday and due next Monday.

This might be one of the hardest classes in CS. You know this class is hard when you don't know how to solve any of the hw problem. And after looking at the hw solution, you still don't know how to solve the hw problems.

It's an intro course, yet he spends lecture on math proofs. He speaks in math which is very hard to parse. Reading an equation takes him about 10-15 minutes. Anything is hard to learn with poor phrasing. Pacing of the material was terrible, rushing hard subjects and taking 2 wks on OTP. Avg on hws was in the 30's. GG fam.

Homework based exams, must understand homework questions not just copy. Easy homework if attended lectures and have textbook to use with ctr + f. Professor easy on grading but also very knowledgeable. Around 5 homeworks, each 3-6 hours to complete (solid studying ,no fb nor snapchat). Disadvantage - Professor has mild accent
